id.desc: Component ID, not specified by default. If specified, it can be used to refer the component in option or API.

name.desc: Series name used for displaying in [tooltip](~tooltip) and filtering with [legend](~legend), or updating data and configuration with `setOption`.

colorBy.desc:
> Since `v5.2.0`



The policy to take color from [option.color](~color). Valid values:

+ `'series'`: assigns the colors in the palette by series, so that all data in the same series are in the same color;
+ `'data'`: assigns colors in the palette according to data items, with each data item using a different color.

legendHoverLink.desc: Whether to enable highlighting chart when [legend](~legend) is being hovered.

selectedMode.desc:
Selected mode.  It is enabled by default, and you may set it to be `false` to disabled it.

Besides, it can be set to `'single'` or `'multiple'`, for single selection and multiple selections.

selectedOffset.desc: The offset distance of selected sector.

clockwise.desc: Whether the layout of sectors of pie chart is clockwise.

startAngle.desc: The start angle, which range is [0, 360].

minAngle.desc: The minimum angle of sector (0 ~ 360). It prevents some sector from being too small when value is small, which will affect user interaction.

minShowLabelAngle.desc: If a sector is less than this angle (0 ~ 360), label and labelLine will not be displayed.

roseType.desc:
Whether to show as Nightingale chart, which distinguishs data through radius. There are 2 optional modes:

+ `'radius'` Use central angle to show the percentage of data, radius to show data size.
+ `'area'` All the sectors will share the same central angle, the data size is shown only through radiuses.

avoidLabelOverlap.desc: Whether to enable the strategy to avoid labels overlap. Defaults to be enabled, which will move the label positions in the case of labels overlapping

stillShowZeroSum.desc: Whether to show sector when all data are zero.

cursor.desc: The mouse style when mouse hovers on an element, the same as `cursor` property in `CSS`.

zlevel.desc:
`zlevel` value of all graphical elements in .

`zlevel` is used to make layers with Canvas. Graphical elements with different `zlevel` values will be placed in different Canvases, which is a common optimization technique. We can put those frequently changed elements (like those with animations) to a separate `zlevel`. Notice that too many Canvases will increase memory cost, and should be used carefully on mobile phones to avoid crash.

Canvases with bigger `zlevel` will be placed on Canvases with smaller `zlevel`.

z.desc:
`z` value of all graphical elements in , which controls order of drawing graphical components. Components with smaller `z` values may be overwritten by those with larger `z` values.

`z` has a lower priority to `zlevel`, and will not create new Canvas.

left.desc:
Distance between pie chart component and the left side of the container.

`left` value can be instant pixel value like `20`; it can also be a percentage value relative to container width like `'20%'`; and it can also be `'left'`, `'center'`, or `'right'`.

If the `left` value is set to be `'left'`, `'center'`, or `'right'`, then the component will be aligned automatically based on position.

top.desc:
Distance between pie chart component and the top side of the container.

`top` value can be instant pixel value like `20`; it can also be a percentage value relative to container width like `'20%'`; and it can also be `'top'`, `'middle'`, or `'bottom'`.

If the `left` value is set to be `'top'`, `'middle'`, or `'bottom'`, then the component will be aligned automatically based on position.

right.desc:
Distance between pie chart component and the right side of the container.

`right` value can be instant pixel value like `20`; it can also be a percentage value relative to container width like `'20%'`.

Adaptive by default.

bottom.desc:
Distance between pie chart component and the bottom side of the container.

`bottom` value can be instant pixel value like `20`; it can also be a percentage value relative to container width like `'20%'`.

Adaptive by default.

width.desc: Width of pie chart component. Adaptive by default.

height.desc: Height of pie chart component. Adaptive by default.

showEmptyCircle.desc: If display an placeholder circle when there is no data.

emptyCircleStyle.color.desc:
color.



> Supports setting as solid color using `rgb(255,255,255)`, `rgba(255,255,255,1)`, `#fff`, etc. Also supports setting as gradient color and pattern fill, see [option.color](~color) for details

emptyCircleStyle.borderColor.desc: border color, whose format is similar to that of `color`.

emptyCircleStyle.borderWidth.desc:
border width. No border when it is set to be 0.

(${name} ? ${name} : "") + " border width. No border when it is set to be 0."

emptyCircleStyle.borderType.desc:
border type.



Possible values are:
+ `'solid'`
+ `'dashed'`
+ `'dotted'`

Since `v5.0.0`, it can also be a number or a number array to specify the [dash array](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/SVG/Attribute/stroke-dasharray) of the line. With
`borderDashOffset`
, we can make the line style more flexible.

For example：
```js
{

borderType: [5, 10],

borderDashOffset: 5
}
```

emptyCircleStyle.borderDashOffset.desc:
> Since `v5.0.0`





To set the line dash offset. With
`borderType`
, we can make the line style more flexible.

Refer to MDN [lineDashOffset](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/lineDashOffset) for more details.

emptyCircleStyle.borderCap.desc:
> Since `v5.0.0`





To specify how to draw the end points of the line.
Possible values are:
+ `'butt'`: The ends of lines are squared off at the endpoints.
+ `'round'`: The ends of lines are rounded.
+ `'square'`: The ends of lines are squared off by adding a box with an equal width and half the height of the line's thickness.

Default value is `'butt'`. Refer to MDN [lineCap](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/lineCap) for more details.

emptyCircleStyle.borderJoin.desc:
> Since `v5.0.0`





To determine the shape used to join two line segments where they meet.

Possible values are:
+ `'bevel'`: Fills an additional triangular area between the common endpoint of connected segments, and the separate outside rectangular corners of each segment.
+ `'round'`: Rounds off the corners of a shape by filling an additional sector of disc centered at the common endpoint of connected segments. The radius for these rounded corners is equal to the line width.
+ `'miter'`: Connected segments are joined by extending their outside edges to connect at a single point, with the effect of filling an additional lozenge-shaped area. This setting is affected by the
`borderMiterLimit`
property.

Default value is `'bevel'`. Refer to MDN [lineJoin](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/lineJoin) for more details.

emptyCircleStyle.borderMiterLimit.desc:
> Since `v5.0.0`





To set the miter limit ratio. Only works when
`borderJoin`
is set as `miter`.

Default value is `10`. Negative、`0`、`Infinity` and `NaN` values are ignored.

Refer to MDN [miterLimit](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/miterLimit) for more details.

emptyCircleStyle.shadowBlur.desc:
Size of shadow blur. This attribute should be used along with `shadowColor`,`shadowOffsetX`, `shadowOffsetY` to set shadow to component.

For example:
```js
{
shadowColor: 'rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.5)',
shadowBlur: 10
}
```

emptyCircleStyle.shadowColor.desc: Shadow color. Support same format as `color`.

emptyCircleStyle.shadowOffsetX.desc: Offset distance on the horizontal direction of shadow.

emptyCircleStyle.shadowOffsetY.desc: Offset distance on the vertical direction of shadow.

emptyCircleStyle.opacity.desc: Opacity of the component. Supports value from 0 to 1, and the component will not be drawn when set to 0.

label.desc: Text label of pie chart, to explain some data information about graphic item like value, name and so on. `label` is placed under `itemStyle` in ECharts 2.x. In ECharts 3, to make the configuration structure flatter, `label`is taken to be at the same level with `itemStyle`, and has `emphasis` as `itemStyle` does.

label.position.desc:
The position of label.

**Options: **
+ `'outside'`

Outside of sectors of pie chart, which relates to corresponding sector through [visual guide line](~series-pie.labelLine).

+ `'inside'`

Inside the sectors of pie chart.

+ `'inner'` is the same with `'inside'`.
+ `'center'`

In the center of pie chart. See [pie-doughnut example](pie-doughnut)

label.rotate.desc:
Label rotation.

+ If `true`, layout label radically.
+ If `number`, means degree that labels are rotated. From -90 degree to 90 degree. The negative value represents clockwise.

label.borderColor.desc: Border color of the text fragment.

label.borderWidth.desc: Border width of the text fragment.

label.borderType.desc:
the text fragment border type.



Possible values are:
+ `'solid'`
+ `'dashed'`
+ `'dotted'`

Since `v5.0.0`, it can also be a number or a number array to specify the [dash array](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/SVG/Attribute/stroke-dasharray) of the line. With
`borderDashOffset`
, we can make the line style more flexible.

For example：
```js
{

borderType: [5, 10],

borderDashOffset: 5
}
```

label.borderDashOffset.desc:
> Since `v5.0.0`





To set the line dash offset. With
`borderType`
, we can make the line style more flexible.

Refer to MDN [lineDashOffset](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/lineDashOffset) for more details.

label.borderRadius.desc: Border radius of the text fragment.

label.padding.desc:
Padding of the text fragment, for example:

+ `padding: [3, 4, 5, 6]`: represents padding of `[top, right, bottom, left]`.
+ `padding: 4`: represents `padding: [4, 4, 4, 4]`.
+ `padding: [3, 4]`: represents `padding: [3, 4, 3, 4]`.

Notice, `width` and `height` specifies the width and height of the content, without `padding`.

label.shadowColor.desc: Shadow color of the text block.

label.shadowBlur.desc: Show blur of the text block.

label.shadowOffsetX.desc: Shadow X offset of the text block.

label.shadowOffsetY.desc: Shadow Y offset of the text block.

label.textBorderWidth.desc: Storke line width of the text.

label.textBorderType.desc:
Stroke line type of the text.


Possible values are:
+ `'solid'`
+ `'dashed'`
+ `'dotted'`

Since `v5.0.0`, it can also be a number or a number array to specify the [dash array](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/SVG/Attribute/stroke-dasharray) of the line. With
`textBorderDashOffset`
, we can make the line style more flexible.

For example：
```js
{

textBorderType: [5, 10],

textBorderDashOffset: 5
}
```

label.textBorderDashOffset.desc:
> Since `v5.0.0`





To set the line dash offset. With
`textBorderType`
, we can make the line style more flexible.

Refer to MDN [lineDashOffset](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/lineDashOffset) for more details.

label.textShadowColor.desc: Shadow color of the text itself.

label.textShadowBlur.desc: Shadow blue of the text itself.

label.textShadowOffsetX.desc: Shadow X offset of the text itself.

label.textShadowOffsetY.desc: Shadow Y offset of the text itself.

label.overflow.desc:
Determine how to display the text when it's overflow. Available when `width` is set.

+ `'truncate'` Truncate the text and trailing with `ellipsis`.
+ `'break'` Break by word
+ `'breakAll'` Break by character.

label.ellipsis.desc: Ellipsis to be displayed when `overflow` is set to `truncate`.

label.lineOverflow.desc:
Determine how to display the text when it's overflow on height.

+ `'truncate'` Truncate the overflow lines.

label.rich.<style_name>.borderColor.desc: Border color of the text fragment.

label.rich.<style_name>.borderWidth.desc: Border width of the text fragment.

label.rich.<style_name>.borderType.desc:
the text fragment border type.



Possible values are:
+ `'solid'`
+ `'dashed'`
+ `'dotted'`

Since `v5.0.0`, it can also be a number or a number array to specify the [dash array](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/SVG/Attribute/stroke-dasharray) of the line. With
`borderDashOffset`
, we can make the line style more flexible.

For example：
```js
{

borderType: [5, 10],

borderDashOffset: 5
}
```

label.rich.<style_name>.borderDashOffset.desc:
> Since `v5.0.0`





To set the line dash offset. With
`borderType`
, we can make the line style more flexible.

Refer to MDN [lineDashOffset](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/lineDashOffset) for more details.

label.rich.<style_name>.borderRadius.desc: Border radius of the text fragment.

label.rich.<style_name>.padding.desc:
Padding of the text fragment, for example:

+ `padding: [3, 4, 5, 6]`: represents padding of `[top, right, bottom, left]`.
+ `padding: 4`: represents `padding: [4, 4, 4, 4]`.
+ `padding: [3, 4]`: represents `padding: [3, 4, 3, 4]`.

Notice, `width` and `height` specifies the width and height of the content, without `padding`.

label.rich.<style_name>.shadowColor.desc: Shadow color of the text block.

label.rich.<style_name>.shadowBlur.desc: Show blur of the text block.

label.rich.<style_name>.shadowOffsetX.desc: Shadow X offset of the text block.

label.rich.<style_name>.shadowOffsetY.desc: Shadow Y offset of the text block.

label.rich.<style_name>.width.desc:
Width of the text block. It is the width of the text by default. In most cases, there is no need to specify it. You may want to use it in some cases like make simple table or using background image (see `backgroundColor`).

Notice, `width` and `height` specifies the width and height of the content, without `padding`.

`width` can also be percent string, like `'100%'`, which represents the percent of `contentWidth` (that is, the width without `padding`) of its container box. It is based on `contentWidth` because that each text fragment is layout based on the `content box`, where it makes no sense that calculating width based on `outerWith` in prectice.


Notice, `width` and `height` only work when `rich` specified.

label.rich.<style_name>.height.desc:
Height of the text block. It is the width of the text by default. You may want to use it in some cases like using background image (see `backgroundColor`).

Notice, `width` and `height` specifies the width and height of the content, without `padding`.

Notice, `width` and `height` only work when `rich` specified.

label.rich.<style_name>.textBorderWidth.desc: Storke line width of the text.

label.rich.<style_name>.textBorderType.desc:
Stroke line type of the text.


Possible values are:
+ `'solid'`
+ `'dashed'`
+ `'dotted'`

Since `v5.0.0`, it can also be a number or a number array to specify the [dash array](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/SVG/Attribute/stroke-dasharray) of the line. With
`textBorderDashOffset`
, we can make the line style more flexible.

For example：
```js
{

textBorderType: [5, 10],

textBorderDashOffset: 5
}
```

label.rich.<style_name>.textBorderDashOf.desc:
> Since `v5.0.0`





To set the line dash offset. With
`textBorderType`
, we can make the line style more flexible.

Refer to MDN [lineDashOffset](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/lineDashOffset) for more details.

label.rich.<style_name>.textShadowColor.desc: Shadow color of the text itself.

label.rich.<style_name>.textShadowBlur.desc: Shadow blue of the text itself.

label.rich.<style_name>.textShadowOffset.desc: Shadow X offset of the text itself.
Shadow Y offset of the text itself.

label.alignTo.desc:
Label aligning policy. Valid only when `position` is `'outer'`.

Since ECharts v4.6.0, we provide `'labelLine'` and `'edge'` two extra valid `alignTo` values.

+ `'none'` (default): label lines have fixed length as [labelLine.length](~series-pie.labelLine.length) and [labelLine.length2](~series-pie.labelLine.length2).
+ `'labelLine'`: aligning to the end of label lines and the length of the shortest horizontal label lines is configured by [labelLine.length2](~series-pie.labelLine.length2).
+ `'edge'`: aligning to text and the distance between the edges of text and the viewport is configured by [label.edgeDistance](~series-pie.label.edgeDistance).

~[900x250](https://echarts.apache.org/examples/en/view.html?c=pie-alignTo&reset=1&edit=1)

label.edgeDistance.desc:
The horizontal distance between text edges and viewport when [label.position](~series-pie.label.position) is `'outer'` and [label.alignTo](~series-pie.label.alignTo) is `'edge'`.

~[900x250](https://echarts.apache.org/examples/en/view.html?c=doc-example/pie-label-margin&edit=1&reset=1)

In most cases, you need a small `edgeDistance` value like `10` for mobile devices to make sure more text can be shown instead of being `...`. But on larger resolutions, a percentage value should be applied so that the label lines won't be too long. If your chart is used in varied resolutions, it is advised to set [responsive design](tutorial.html#Responsive%20Mobile-End) for different resolutions.

label.bleedMargin.desc:
The horizontal distance between text and viewport when [label.position](~series-pie.label.position) is `'outer'` and [label.alignTo](~series-pie.label.alignTo) is `'none'` or `'labelLine'`. Longer text will be truncated into `'...'`.

~[800x250](https://echarts.apache.org/examples/en/view.html?c=doc-example/pie-label-bleedMargin&edit=1&reset=1)

label.distanceToLabelLine.desc:
Distance between label line and text.

~[800x250](https://echarts.apache.org/examples/en/view.html?c=doc-example/pie-label-distanceToLabelLine&edit=1&reset=1)

labelLine.desc: The style of visual guide line. Will show when [label position](~series-pie.label.position) is set as `'outside'`.

labelLine.show.desc: Whether to show the label guide line.

labelLine.showAbove.desc: Whether to show the label guide line above the corresponding element.

labelLine.length.desc: The length of the first segment of guide line.

labelLine.length2.desc: The length of the second segment of guide line.

labelLine.smooth.desc: Whether to smooth the guide line. It defaults to be `false` and can be set as `true` or the values from 0 to 1 which indicating the smoothness.

labelLine.minTurnAngle.desc:
Minimum turn angle between two segments of guide line to prevent unaesthetic display when angle is too small.

Can be 0 - 180 degree.

labelLine.lineStyle.color.desc:
Line color.





> Supports setting as solid color using `rgb(255,255,255)`, `rgba(255,255,255,1)`, `#fff`, etc. Also supports setting as gradient color and pattern fill, see [option.color](~color) for details

labelLine.lineStyle.type.desc:
line type.


Possible values are:
+ `'solid'`
+ `'dashed'`
+ `'dotted'`

Since `v5.0.0`, it can also be a number or a number array to specify the [dash array](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/SVG/Attribute/stroke-dasharray) of the line. With
`dashOffset`
, we can make the line style more flexible.

For example：
```js
{

type: [5, 10],

dashOffset: 5
}
```

labelLine.lineStyle.dashOffset.desc:
> Since `v5.0.0`





To set the line dash offset. With
`type`
, we can make the line style more flexible.

Refer to MDN [lineDashOffset](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/lineDashOffset) for more details.

labelLine.lineStyle.cap.desc:
> Since `v5.0.0`





To specify how to draw the end points of the line.
Possible values are:
+ `'butt'`: The ends of lines are squared off at the endpoints.
+ `'round'`: The ends of lines are rounded.
+ `'square'`: The ends of lines are squared off by adding a box with an equal width and half the height of the line's thickness.

Default value is `'butt'`. Refer to MDN [lineCap](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/lineCap) for more details.

labelLine.lineStyle.join.desc:
> Since `v5.0.0`





To determine the shape used to join two line segments where they meet.

Possible values are:
+ `'bevel'`: Fills an additional triangular area between the common endpoint of connected segments, and the separate outside rectangular corners of each segment.
+ `'round'`: Rounds off the corners of a shape by filling an additional sector of disc centered at the common endpoint of connected segments. The radius for these rounded corners is equal to the line width.
+ `'miter'`: Connected segments are joined by extending their outside edges to connect at a single point, with the effect of filling an additional lozenge-shaped area. This setting is affected by the
`miterLimit`
property.

Default value is `'bevel'`. Refer to MDN [lineJoin](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/lineJoin) for more details.

labelLine.lineStyle.miterLimit.desc:
> Since `v5.0.0`





To set the miter limit ratio. Only works when
`join`
is set as `miter`.

Default value is `10`. Negative、`0`、`Infinity` and `NaN` values are ignored.

Refer to MDN [miterLimit](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/miterLimit) for more details.

labelLine.lineStyle.shadowBlur.desc:
Size of shadow blur. This attribute should be used along with `shadowColor`,`shadowOffsetX`, `shadowOffsetY` to set shadow to component.

For example:
```js
{
shadowColor: 'rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.5)',
shadowBlur: 10
}
```

labelLine.lineStyle.shadowColor.desc: Shadow color. Support same format as `color`.

labelLine.lineStyle.shadowOffsetX.desc: Offset distance on the horizontal direction of shadow.

labelLine.lineStyle.shadowOffsetY.desc: Offset distance on the vertical direction of shadow.

labelLine.lineStyle.opacity.desc: Opacity of the component. Supports value from 0 to 1, and the component will not be drawn when set to 0.

labelLine.maxSurfaceAngle.desc:
Max angle between guide line and surface normal. To prevent guide line overlapping with sector.

Can be 0 - 180 degree.

labelLayout.hideOverlap.desc:
If hide the overlapped labels.

The following example shows how to hide the overlapped labels in graph automatically when zooming.

~[600x400](graph-label-overlap&edit=1&reset=1)

labelLayout.moveOverlap.desc:
If move the overlapped labels to avoid overlapping.

Currently supported configurations:

+ `'shiftX'` Place the labels on horizontal direction sequencely, used when aligned horizontally.
+ `'shiftY'` Place the labels on vertial direction sequencely, used when aligned vertically.

The following example shows how to use `moverOverlap: 'shiftY'` to place the labels aligned vertically.

~[600x400](scatter-label-align-right&edit=1&reset=1)

labelLayout.x.desc: The x position of the label. Support absolute pixel values ​​or relative values ​​such as `'20%'`.

labelLayout.y.desc: The y position of the label. Support absolute pixel values ​​or relative values ​​such as `'20%'`.

labelLayout.dx.desc: The pixel offset of the label in the x direction. Can be used with `x`.

labelLayout.dy.desc: The pixel offset of the label in the y direction. Can be used with `y`

labelLayout.width.desc: The width of displayed label. Can be used with `overflow` to constraint the label in a fixed width

labelLayout.height.desc: The height of displayed label. Can be used with `lineOverflow` to constraint the label in a fixed height.

labelLayout.align.desc: The horizontal alignment of the label. Can be `'left'`, `'center'`, `'right'`.

labelLayout.verticalAlign.desc: The vertical alignment of the label. Can be `'top'`, `'middle'`, `'bottom'`.

labelLayout.fontSize.desc: The text size of the label.

labelLayout.draggable.desc: Whether to allow the user to adjust the position by dragging.

labelLayout.labelLinePoints.desc:
The array of the three points of the label guide line. The format is:

```js
[[x, y], [x, y], [x, y]]
```

It is often used in pie charts to fine-tune the guide line that has been calculated. Usually not recommended to set it in other situations.

itemStyle.desc: Graphic style of , `emphasis` is the style when it is highlighted, like being hovered by mouse, or highlighted via legend connect.

itemStyle.color.desc:
color. Color is taken from [option.color Palette](~color) by default.



> Supports setting as solid color using `rgb(255,255,255)`, `rgba(255,255,255,1)`, `#fff`, etc. Also supports setting as gradient color and pattern fill, see [option.color](~color) for details




Supports callback functions, in the form of:
```js
(params: Object) => Color
```
Input parameters are `seriesIndex`, `dataIndex`, `data`, `value`, and etc. of data item.

itemStyle.borderColor.desc: border color, whose format is similar to that of `color`.

itemStyle.borderWidth.desc:
border width. No border when it is set to be 0.

(${name} ? ${name} : "") + " border width. No border when it is set to be 0."

itemStyle.borderType.desc:
border type.



Possible values are:
+ `'solid'`

itemStyle.borderJoin.desc:
> Since `v5.0.0`





To determine the shape used to join two line segments where they meet.

Possible values are:
+ `'bevel'`: Fills an additional triangular area between the common endpoint of connected segments, and the separate outside rectangular corners of each segment.
+ `'round'`: Rounds off the corners of a shape by filling an additional sector of disc centered at the common endpoint of connected segments. The radius for these rounded corners is equal to the line width.
+ `'miter'`: Connected segments are joined by extending their outside edges to connect at a single point, with the effect of filling an additional lozenge-shaped area. This setting is affected by the
`borderMiterLimit`
property.

Default value is `'bevel'`. Refer to MDN [lineJoin](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/lineJoin) for more details.

itemStyle.borderMiterLimit.desc:
> Since `v5.0.0`





To set the miter limit ratio. Only works when
`borderJoin`
is set as `miter`.

Default value is `10`. Negative、`0`、`Infinity` and `NaN` values are ignored.

Refer to MDN [miterLimit](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/miterLimit) for more details.

itemStyle.shadowBlur.desc:
Size of shadow blur. This attribute should be used along with `shadowColor`,`shadowOffsetX`, `shadowOffsetY` to set shadow to component.

For example:
```js
{
shadowColor: 'rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.5)',
shadowBlur: 10
}
```

itemStyle.shadowColor.desc: Shadow color. Support same format as `color`.

itemStyle.shadowOffsetX.desc: Offset distance on the horizontal direction of shadow.

itemStyle.shadowOffsetY.desc: Offset distance on the vertical direction of shadow.

itemStyle.opacity.desc: Opacity of the component. Supports value from 0 to 1, and the component will not be drawn when set to 0.

itemStyle.decal.desc:
The style of the decal pattern. It works only if [aria.enabled](~aria.enabled) and [aria.decal.show](~aria.decal.show) are both set to be `true`.

If it is set to be `'none'`, no decal will be used.

itemStyle.decal.symbol.desc:
The symbol type of the decal. If it is in the type of `string[]`, it means the symbols are used one by one.



Icon types provided by ECharts includes



`'circle'`, `'rect'`, `'roundRect'`, `'triangle'`, `'diamond'`, `'pin'`, `'arrow'`, `'none'`







It can be set to an image with `'image://url'` , in which URL is the link to an image, or `dataURI` of an image.


An image URL example:

```
'image://http://xxx.xxx.xxx/a/b.png'
```

A `dataURI` example:

```
'image://data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhEAAQAMQAAORHHOVSKudfOulrSOp3WOyDZu6QdvCchPGolfO0o/XBs/fNwfjZ0frl3/zy7////wAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAACH5BAkAABAALAAAAAAQABAAAAVVICSOZGlCQAosJ6mu7fiyZeKqNKToQGDsM8hBADgUXoGAiqhSvp5QAnQKGIgUhwFUYLCVDFCrKUE1lBavAViFIDlTImbKC5Gm2hB0SlBCBMQiB0UjIQA7'
```



Icons can be set to arbitrary vector path via `'path://'` in ECharts. As compared with a raster image, vector paths prevent jagging and blurring when scaled, and have better control over changing colors. The size of the vector icon will be adapted automatically. Refer to [SVG PathData](http://www.w3.org/TR/SVG/paths.html#PathData) for more information about the format of the path. You may export vector paths from tools like Adobe

For example:

```
'path://M30.9,53.2C16.8,53.2,5.3,41.7,5.3,27.6S16.8,2,30.9,2C45,2,56.4,13.5,56.4,27.6S45,53.2,30.9,53.2z M30.9,3.5C17.6,3.5,6.8,14.4,6.8,27.6c0,13.3,10.8,24.1,24.101,24.1C44.2,51.7,55,40.9,55,27.6C54.9,14.4,44.1,3.5,30.9,3.5z M36.9,35.8c0,0.601-0.4,1-0.9,1h-1.3c-0.5,0-0.9-0.399-0.9-1V19.5c0-0.6,0.4-1,0.9-1H36c0.5,0,0.9,0.4,0.9,1V35.8z M27.8,35.8 c0,0.601-0.4,1-0.9,1h-1.3c-0.5,0-0.9-0.399-0.9-1V19.5c0-0.6,0.4-1,0.9-1H27c0.5,0,0.9,0.4,0.9,1L27.8,35.8L27.8,35.8z'
```

itemStyle.decal.symbolSize.desc: Range of values: `0` to `1`, representing the size of symbol relative to decal.

itemStyle.decal.symbolKeepAspect.desc: Whether or not to keep the aspect ratio of the pattern.

itemStyle.decal.color.desc: For the color of the decal pattern, it is recommended to use a translucent color, which can be superimposed on the color of the series itself.

itemStyle.decal.backgroundColor.desc: The background color of the decal will be over the color of the series itself, under the decal pattern.

itemStyle.decal.dashArrayX.desc:
The basic pattern of the decal pattern is an infinite loop in the form of `Pattern - Blank - Pattern - Blank - Pattern - Blank` both horizontally and vertically, respectively. By setting the length of each pattern and blank, complex pattern effects can be achieved.

`dashArrayX` controls the horizontal pattern pattern. When its value is of type `number` or `number[]`, it is similar to [SVG stroke-dasharray](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/SVG/Attribute/stroke-dasharray).

- If it is of type `number`, it means that the pattern and the blank space are of this value respectively. For example, `5` means the pattern with width 5 is displayed first, then 5 pixels empty, then the pattern with width 5 is displayed...

- In the case of `number[]` type, it means that the pattern and empty space are loops of an array of values. For example: `[5, 10, 2, 6]` means the pattern is 5 pixels wide, then 10 pixels empty, then the pattern is 2 pixels wide, then 6 pixels empty, then the pattern is 5 pixels wide...

- If of type `(number | number[])[]`, it means that each row is a loop with an array of values for the pattern and blank space. For example: `[10, [2, 5]]` means that the first line will be 10 pixels by 10 pixels and empty space, the second line will be 2 pixels by 2 pixels and empty space, and the third line will be 10 pixels by 10 pixels and empty space...

This interface can be better understood with the following examples.

~[700x300](doc-example/aria-decal&edit=1&reset=1)

itemStyle.decal.dashArrayY.desc:
The basic pattern of the decal pattern is an infinite loop in the form of `Pattern - Blank - Pattern - Blank - Pattern - Blank` both horizontally and vertically, respectively. By setting the length of each pattern and blank, complex pattern effects can be achieved.

`dashArrayY` controls the horizontal pattern pattern. Similar to [SVG stroke-dasharray](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/SVG/Attribute/stroke-dasharray).

- If it is a `number` type, it means the pattern and the blank are each of this value. For example, `5` means that the pattern with a height of 5 is displayed first, then 5 pixels empty, then the pattern with a height of 5 is displayed...

- In the case of `number[]` type, it means that the pattern and empty space are loops of sequential array values. For example: `[5, 10, 2, 6]` means the pattern is 5 pixels high, then 10 pixels empty, then the pattern is 2 pixels high, then 6 pixels empty, then the pattern is 5 pixels high...

This interface can be better understood with the following examples.

~[700x300](doc-example/aria-decal&edit=1&reset=1)

itemStyle.decal.rotation.desc: The overall rotation angle (in radians) of the pattern, in the range from `-Math.

itemStyle.decal.maxTileWidth.desc: The upper limit of the width of the generated pattern before it is duplicated. Usually this value is not necessary, but you can try to increase it if you notice discontinuous seams in the pattern when it repeats.

itemStyle.decal.maxTileHeight.desc: The upper limit of the height of the generated pattern before it repeats. This value is usually not necessary to set, but you can try to increase it if you find that the pattern has discontinuous seams when it is repeated.

itemStyle.borderRadius.desc:
> Since `v5.0.0`



To specify the roundness for corners of the sectors of the pie chart. It can be either a specific pixel value or a percentage value relative to the radius of the sector.

+ `borderRadius: 10`: means that both inner corner radius and outer corner radius are `10px`.
+ `borderRadius: '20%'`: means that both inner corner radius is `20%` of the inner radius of the pie and outer corner radius is `20%` of the outer radius of the pie.
+ `borderRadius: [10, 20]`: means that the inner corner radius is `10px` and the outer corner radius is `20px`.
+ `borderRadius: ['20%', '50%']`: means that the inner corner radius is `20%` of the inner radius of the pie and the outer corner radius is `50%` of the outer radius of the pie.

emphasis.scale.desc: Whether to scale to highlight the data in emphasis state.

emphasis.scaleSize.desc: Size of scale. Available when [emphasis.scale](~series-pie.emphasis.scale) is set `true`.

emphasis.focus.desc:
> Since `v5.0.0`




When the data is highlighted, whether to fade out of other data to focus the highlighted. The following configurations are supported:

+ `'none'` Do not fade out other data, it's by default.
+ `'self'` Only focus (not fade out) the element of the currently highlighted data.


+ `'series'` Focus on all elements of the series which the currently highlighted data belongs to.




**Example: **


```js
emphasis: {
focus: 'series',
blurScope: 'coordinateSystem'
}
```

~[600x400](bar-y-category-stack&reset=1&edit=1)

emphasis.blurScope.desc:
> Since `v5.0.0`



The range of fade out when `focus` is enabled. Support the following configurations

+ `'coordinateSystem'`
+ `'series'`
+ `'global'`

emphasis.label.rotate.desc:
Label rotation.

+ If `true`, layout label radically.
+ If `number`, means degree that labels are rotated. From -90 degree to 90 degree. The negative value represents clockwise.

emphasis.label.borderColor.desc: Border color of the text fragment.

emphasis.label.borderWidth.desc: Border width of the text fragment.

emphasis.label.borderType.desc:
the text fragment border type.



Possible values are:
+ `'solid'`
+ `'dashed'`
+ `'dotted'`

Since `v5.0.0`, it can also be a number or a number array to specify the [dash array](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/SVG/Attribute/stroke-dasharray) of the line. With
`borderDashOffset`
, we can make the line style more flexible.

For example：
```js
{

borderType: [5, 10],

borderDashOffset: 5
}
```

emphasis.label.borderDashOffset.desc:
> Since `v5.0.0`





To set the line dash offset. With
`borderType`
, we can make the line style more flexible.

Refer to MDN [lineDashOffset](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/lineDashOffset) for more details.

emphasis.label.borderRadius.desc: Border radius of the text fragment.

emphasis.label.padding.desc:
Padding of the text fragment, for example:

+ `padding: [3, 4, 5, 6]`: represents padding of `[top, right, bottom, left]`.
+ `padding: 4`: represents `padding: [4, 4, 4, 4]`.
+ `padding: [3, 4]`: represents `padding: [3, 4, 3, 4]`.

Notice, `width` and `height` specifies the width and height of the content, without `padding`.

emphasis.label.shadowColor.desc: Shadow color of the text block.

emphasis.label.shadowBlur.desc: Show blur of the text block.

emphasis.label.shadowOffsetX.desc: Shadow X offset of the text block.

emphasis.label.shadowOffsetY.desc: Shadow Y offset of the text block.

emphasis.label.textBorderWidth.desc: Storke line width of the text.

emphasis.label.textBorderType.desc:
Stroke line type of the text.


Possible values are:
+ `'solid'`
+ `'dashed'`
+ `'dotted'`

Since `v5.0.0`, it can also be a number or a number array to specify the [dash array](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/SVG/Attribute/stroke-dasharray) of the line. With
`textBorderDashOffset`
, we can make the line style more flexible.

For example：
```js

textBorderDashOffset: 5

```

emphasis.label.textShadowBlur.desc: Shadow blue of the text itself.

emphasis.label.textShadowOffsetX.desc: Shadow X offset of the text itself.

emphasis.label.textShadowOffsetY.desc: Shadow Y offset of the text itself.

emphasis.label.overflow.desc:
Determine how to display the text when it's overflow. Available when `width` is set.

+ `'truncate'` Truncate the text and trailing with `ellipsis`.
+ `'break'` Break by word
+ `'breakAll'` Break by character.

emphasis.label.ellipsis.desc: Ellipsis to be displayed when `overflow` is set to `truncate`.

emphasis.label.lineOverflow.desc:
Determine how to display the text when it's overflow on height.

+ `'truncate'` Truncate the overflow lines.

emphasis.label.rich.<style_name>.borderW.desc: Border width of the text fragment.

emphasis.label.rich.<style_name>.padding.desc:
Padding of the text fragment, for example:

+ `padding: [3, 4, 5, 6]`: represents padding of `[top, right, bottom, left]`.
+ `padding: 4`: represents `padding: [4, 4, 4, 4]`.
+ `padding: [3, 4]`: represents `padding: [3, 4, 3, 4]`.

Notice, `width` and `height` specifies the width and height of the content, without `padding`.

emphasis.label.rich.<style_name>.shadowC.desc: Shadow color of the text block.

emphasis.label.rich.<style_name>.shadowB.desc: Show blur of the text block.

emphasis.label.rich.<style_name>.shadowO.desc: Shadow X offset of the text block.
Shadow Y offset of the text block.

emphasis.label.rich.<style_name>.width.desc:
Width of the text block. It is the width of the text by default. In most cases, there is no need to specify it. You may want to use it in some cases like make simple table or using background image (see `backgroundColor`).

Notice, `width` and `height` specifies the width and height of the content, without `padding`.

`width` can also be percent string, like `'100%'`, which represents the percent of `contentWidth` (that is, the width without `padding`) of its container box. It is based on `contentWidth` because that each text fragment is layout based on the `content box`, where it makes no sense that calculating width based on `outerWith` in prectice.


Notice, `width` and `height` only work when `rich` specified.

emphasis.label.rich.<style_name>.height.desc:
Height of the text block. It is the width of the text by default. You may want to use it in some cases like using background image (see `backgroundColor`).

Notice, `width` and `height` specifies the width and height of the content, without `padding`.

Notice, `width` and `height` only work when `rich` specified.

emphasis.label.rich.<style_name>.textBor.desc: Storke line width of the text.

Stroke line type of the text.


Possible values are:
+ `'solid'`
+ `'dashed'`

Since `v5.0.0`, it can also be a number or a number array to specify the [dash array](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/SVG/Attribute/stroke-dasharray) of the line. With
`textBorderDashOffset`
, we can make the line style more flexible.

For example：
```js

}
```

emphasis.labelLine.show.desc: Whether to show the label guide line.

emphasis.labelLine.lineStyle.color.desc:
Line color.





> Supports setting as solid color using `rgb(255,255,255)`, `rgba(255,255,255,1)`, `#fff`, etc. Also supports setting as gradient color and pattern fill, see [option.color](~color) for details

emphasis.labelLine.lineStyle.type.desc:
line type.


Possible values are:
+ `'solid'`
+ `'dashed'`
+ `'dotted'`

Since `v5.0.0`, it can also be a number or a number array to specify the [dash array](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/SVG/Attribute/stroke-dasharray) of the line. With
`dashOffset`
, we can make the line style more flexible.

For example：
```js
{

type: [5, 10],

dashOffset: 5
}
```

emphasis.labelLine.lineStyle.dashOffset.desc:
> Since `v5.0.0`





To set the line dash offset. With
`type`
, we can make the line style more flexible.

Refer to MDN [lineDashOffset](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/lineDashOffset) for more details.

emphasis.labelLine.lineStyle.cap.desc:
> Since `v5.0.0`





To specify how to draw the end points of the line.
Possible values are:
+ `'butt'`: The ends of lines are squared off at the endpoints.
+ `'round'`: The ends of lines are rounded.
+ `'square'`: The ends of lines are squared off by adding a box with an equal width and half the height of the line's thickness.

Default value is `'butt'`. Refer to MDN [lineCap](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/lineCap) for more details.

emphasis.labelLine.lineStyle.join.desc:
> Since `v5.0.0`





To determine the shape used to join two line segments where they meet.

Possible values are:
+ `'bevel'`: Fills an additional triangular area between the common endpoint of connected segments, and the separate outside rectangular corners of each segment.
+ `'round'`: Rounds off the corners of a shape by filling an additional sector of disc centered at the common endpoint of connected segments. The radius for these rounded corners is equal to the line width.
+ `'miter'`: Connected segments are joined by extending their outside edges to connect at a single point, with the effect of filling an additional lozenge-shaped area. This setting is affected by the
`miterLimit`
property.

Default value is `'bevel'`. Refer to MDN [lineJoin](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/lineJoin) for more details.

emphasis.labelLine.lineStyle.miterLimit.desc:
> Since `v5.0.0`





To set the miter limit ratio. Only works when
`join`
is set as `miter`.

Default value is `10`. Negative、`0`、`Infinity` and `NaN` values are ignored.

Refer to MDN [miterLimit](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/miterLimit) for more details.

emphasis.labelLine.lineStyle.shadowBlur.desc:
Size of shadow blur. This attribute should be used along with `shadowColor`,`shadowOffsetX`, `shadowOffsetY` to set shadow to component.

For example:
```js
{
shadowColor: 'rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.5)',
shadowBlur: 10
}
```

blur.label.textBorderWidth.desc: Storke line width of the text.

blur.label.textBorderType.desc:
Stroke line type of the text.


Possible values are:
+ `'solid'`
+ `'dashed'`
+ `'dotted'`

Since `v5.0.0`, it can also be a number or a number array to specify the [dash array](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/SVG/Attribute/stroke-dasharray) of the line. With
`textBorderDashOffset`
, we can make the line style more flexible.

For example：
```js
{

textBorderType: [5, 10],

textBorderDashOffset: 5
}
```

blur.label.textBorderDashOffset.desc:
> Since `v5.0.0`





To set the line dash offset. With
`textBorderType`
, we can make the line style more flexible.

Refer to MDN [lineDashOffset](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/lineDashOffset) for more details.

blur.label.textShadowColor.desc: Shadow color of the text itself.

blur.label.textShadowBlur.desc: Shadow blue of the text itself.

blur.label.textShadowOffsetX.desc: Shadow X offset of the text itself.

blur.label.textShadowOffsetY.desc: Shadow Y offset of the text itself.

blur.label.overflow.desc:
Determine how to display the text when it's overflow. Available when `width` is set.

+ `'truncate'` Truncate the text and trailing with `ellipsis`.
+ `'break'` Break by word
+ `'breakAll'` Break by character.

blur.label.ellipsis.desc: Ellipsis to be displayed when `overflow` is set to `truncate`.

blur.label.lineOverflow.desc:
Determine how to display the text when it's overflow on height.

+ `'truncate'` Truncate the overflow lines.

blur.label.rich.<style_name>.borderColor.desc: Border color of the text fragment.

blur.label.rich.<style_name>.borderWidth.desc: Border width of the text fragment.

blur.label.rich.<style_name>.borderType.desc:
the text fragment border type.



Possible values are:
+ `'solid'`
+ `'dashed'`
+ `'dotted'`

Since `v5.0.0`, it can also be a number or a number array to specify the [dash array](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/SVG/Attribute/stroke-dasharray) of the line. With
`borderDashOffset`
, we can make the line style more flexible.

For example：
```js

borderDashOffset: 5
}
```

`borderType`

blur.label.rich.<style_name>.borderRadiu.desc: Border radius of the text fragment.

blur.label.rich.<style_name>.padding.desc:
Padding of the text fragment, for example:

+ `padding: [3, 4, 5, 6]`: represents padding of `[top, right, bottom, left]`.
+ `padding: 4`: represents `padding: [4, 4, 4, 4]`.
+ `padding: [3, 4]`: represents `padding: [3, 4, 3, 4]`.

Notice, `width` and `height` specifies the width and height of the content, without `padding`.

blur.label.rich.<style_name>.shadowColor.desc: Shadow color of the text block.

blur.label.rich.<style_name>.shadowBlur.desc: Show blur of the text block.

blur.label.rich.<style_name>.shadowOffse.desc: Shadow X offset of the text block.
Shadow Y offset of the text block.

blur.label.rich.<style_name>.width.desc:
Width of the text block. It is the width of the text by default. In most cases, there is no need to specify it. You may want to use it in some cases like make simple table or using background image (see `backgroundColor`).

Notice, `width` and `height` specifies the width and height of the content, without `padding`.

`width` can also be percent string, like `'100%'`, which represents the percent of `contentWidth` (that is, the width without `padding`) of its container box. It is based on `contentWidth` because that each text fragment is layout based on the `content box`, where it makes no sense that calculating width based on `outerWith` in prectice.


Notice, `width` and `height` only work when `rich` specified.

blur.label.rich.<style_name>.height.desc:
Height of the text block. It is the width of the text by default. You may want to use it in some cases like using background image (see `backgroundColor`).

Notice, `width` and `height` specifies the width and height of the content, without `padding`.

Notice, `width` and `height` only work when `rich` specified.

blur.label.rich.<style_name>.textBorderW.desc: Storke line width of the text.

blur.label.rich.<style_name>.textShadowB.desc: Shadow blue of the text itself.

blur.label.rich.<style_name>.textShadowO.desc: Shadow X offset of the text itself.
Shadow Y offset of the text itself.

blur.labelLine.show.desc: Whether to show the label guide line.

blur.labelLine.lineStyle.color.desc:
Line color.





> Supports setting as solid color using `rgb(255,255,255)`, `rgba(255,255,255,1)`, `#fff`, etc. Also supports setting as gradient color and pattern fill, see [option.color](~color) for details

blur.labelLine.lineStyle.type.desc:
line type.


Possible values are:
+ `'solid'`
+ `'dashed'`
+ `'dotted'`

Since `v5.0.0`, it can also be a number or a number array to specify the [dash array](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/SVG/Attribute/stroke-dasharray) of the line. With
`dashOffset`
, we can make the line style more flexible.

For example：
```js
{

type: [5, 10],

dashOffset: 5
}
```

blur.labelLine.lineStyle.dashOffset.desc:
> Since `v5.0.0`





To set the line dash offset. With
`type`
, we can make the line style more flexible.

Refer to MDN [lineDashOffset](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/lineDashOffset) for more details.

blur.labelLine.lineStyle.cap.desc:
> Since `v5.0.0`





To specify how to draw the end points of the line.
Possible values are:
+ `'butt'`: The ends of lines are squared off at the endpoints.
+ `'round'`: The ends of lines are rounded.
+ `'square'`: The ends of lines are squared off by adding a box with an equal width and half the height of the line's thickness.

Default value is `'butt'`. Refer to MDN [lineCap](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/lineCap) for more details.

blur.labelLine.lineStyle.join.desc:
> Since `v5.0.0`





To determine the shape used to join two line segments where they meet.

Possible values are:
+ `'bevel'`: Fills an additional triangular area between the common endpoint of connected segments, and the separate outside rectangular corners of each segment.
+ `'round'`: Rounds off the corners of a shape by filling an additional sector of disc centered at the common endpoint of connected segments. The radius for these rounded corners is equal to the line width.
+ `'miter'`: Connected segments are joined by extending their outside edges to connect at a single point, with the effect of filling an additional lozenge-shaped area. This setting is affected by the
`miterLimit`
property.

Default value is `'bevel'`. Refer to MDN [lineJoin](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/lineJoin) for more details.

blur.labelLine.lineStyle.miterLimit.desc:
> Since `v5.0.0`





To set the miter limit ratio. Only works when
`join`
is set as `miter`.

Default value is `10`. Negative、`0`、`Infinity` and `NaN` values are ignored.

Refer to MDN [miterLimit](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/miterLimit) for more details.

blur.labelLine.lineStyle.shadowBlur.desc:
Size of shadow blur. This attribute should be used along with `shadowColor`,`shadowOffsetX`, `shadowOffsetY` to set shadow to component.

For example:
```js
{
shadowColor: 'rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.5)',
shadowBlur: 10
}
```

blur.labelLine.lineStyle.shadowColor.desc: Shadow color. Support same format as `color`.

blur.labelLine.lineStyle.shadowOffsetX.desc: Offset distance on the horizontal direction of shadow.

blur.labelLine.lineStyle.shadowOffsetY.desc: Offset distance on the vertical direction of shadow.

blur.labelLine.lineStyle.opacity.desc: Opacity of the component. Supports value from 0 to 1, and the component will not be drawn when set to 0.

blur.itemStyle.color.desc:
color. Since 5.2.0, it can be set to `'inherit'` in the `emphasis` state to disable color highlight.



> Supports setting as solid color using `rgb(255,255,255)`, `rgba(255,255,255,1)`, `#fff`, etc. Also supports setting as gradient color and pattern fill, see [option.color](~color) for details

blur.itemStyle.borderColor.desc: border color, whose format is similar to that of `color`.

blur.itemStyle.borderWidth.desc:
border width. No border when it is set to be 0.

(${name} ? ${name} : "") + " border width. No border when it is set to be 0."

blur.itemStyle.shadowColor.desc: Shadow color. Support same format as `color`.

blur.itemStyle.shadowOffsetX.desc: Offset distance on the horizontal direction of shadow.

blur.itemStyle.shadowOffsetY.desc: Offset distance on the vertical direction of shadow.

blur.itemStyle.opacity.desc: Opacity of the component. Supports value from 0 to 1, and the component will not be drawn when set to 0.

blur.itemStyle.borderRadius.desc:
> Since `v5.0.0`



To specify the roundness for corners of the sectors of the pie chart. It can be either a specific pixel value or a percentage value relative to the radius of the sector.

+ `borderRadius: 10`: means that both inner corner radius and outer corner radius are `10px`.
+ `borderRadius: '20%'`: means that both inner corner radius is `20%` of the inner radius of the pie and outer corner radius is `20%` of the outer radius of the pie.
+ `borderRadius: [10, 20]`: means that the inner corner radius is `10px` and the outer corner radius is `20px`.
+ `borderRadius: ['20%', '50%']`: means that the inner corner radius is `20%` of the inner radius of the pie and the outer corner radius is `50%` of the outer radius of the pie.

select.label.rotate.desc:

+ If `true`, layout label radically.
+ If `number`, means degree that labels are rotated. From -90 degree to 90 degree. The negative value represents clockwise.

select.itemStyle.borderCap.desc:
> Since `v5.0.0`





To specify how to draw the end points of the line.
Possible values are:
+ `'butt'`: The ends of lines are squared off at the endpoints.
+ `'round'`: The ends of lines are rounded.
+ `'square'`: The ends of lines are squared off by adding a box with an equal width and half the height of the line's thickness.

Default value is `'butt'`. Refer to MDN [lineCap](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/lineCap) for more details.

select.itemStyle.borderJoin.desc:
> Since `v5.0.0`





To determine the shape used to join two line segments where they meet.

Possible values are:
+ `'bevel'`: Fills an additional triangular area between the common endpoint of connected segments, and the separate outside rectangular corners of each segment.
+ `'round'`: Rounds off the corners of a shape by filling an additional sector of disc centered at the common endpoint of connected segments. The radius for these rounded corners is equal to the line width.
+ `'miter'`: Connected segments are joined by extending their outside edges to connect at a single point, with the effect of filling an additional lozenge-shaped area. This setting is affected by the
`borderMiterLimit`
property.

Default value is `'bevel'`. Refer to MDN [lineJoin](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/lineJoin) for more details.

select.itemStyle.borderMiterLimit.desc:
> Since `v5.0.0`





To set the miter limit ratio. Only works when
`borderJoin`
is set as `miter`.

Default value is `10`. Negative、`0`、`Infinity` and `NaN` values are ignored.

Refer to MDN [miterLimit](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/miterLimit) for more details.

select.itemStyle.shadowBlur.desc:
Size of shadow blur. This attribute should be used along with `shadowColor`,`shadowOffsetX`, `shadowOffsetY` to set shadow to component.

For example:
```js
{
shadowColor: 'rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.5)',
shadowBlur: 10
}
```

select.itemStyle.shadowColor.desc: Shadow color. Support same format as `color`.

select.itemStyle.shadowOffsetX.desc: Offset distance on the horizontal direction of shadow.

select.itemStyle.shadowOffsetY.desc: Offset distance on the vertical direction of shadow.

select.itemStyle.opacity.desc: Opacity of the component. Supports value from 0 to 1, and the component will not be drawn when set to 0.

select.itemStyle.borderRadius.desc:
> Since `v5.0.0`



To specify the roundness for corners of the sectors of the pie chart. It can be either a specific pixel value or a percentage value relative to the radius of the sector.

+ `borderRadius: 10`: means that both inner corner radius and outer corner radius are `10px`.
+ `borderRadius: '20%'`: means that both inner corner radius is `20%` of the inner radius of the pie and outer corner radius is `20%` of the outer radius of the pie.
+ `borderRadius: [10, 20]`: means that the inner corner radius is `10px` and the outer corner radius is `20px`.
+ `borderRadius: ['20%', '50%']`: means that the inner corner radius is `20%` of the inner radius of the pie and the outer corner radius is `50%` of the outer radius of the pie.

center.desc:
Center position of Pie chart, the first of which is the horizontal position, and the second is the vertical position.

Percentage is supported. When set in percentage, the item is relative to the container width, and the second item to the height.

**Example: **
```
// Set to absolute pixel values
center: [400, 300]
// Set to relative percent
center: ['50%', '50%']
```

radius.desc:
Radius of Pie chart. Value can be:

+ `number`: Specify outside radius directly.
+ `string`: For example, `'20%'`, means that the outside radius is 20% of the viewport size (the little one between width and height of the chart container).


+ `Array.<number|string>`: The first item specifies the inside radius, and the second item specifies the outside radius. Each item follows the definitions above.




Donut chart can be achieved by setting a inner radius.

seriesLayoutBy.desc:
When [dataset](~dataset) is used, `seriesLayoutBy` specifies whether the column or the row of `dataset` is mapped to the series, namely, the series is "layout" on columns or rows. Optional values:

+ 'column': by default, the columns of `dataset` are mapped the series. In this case, each column represents a dimension.
+ 'row'：the rows of `dataset` are mapped to the series. In this case, each row represents a dimension.

Check this [example](dataset-series-layout-by).

datasetIndex.desc: If [series.data](~series.data) is not specified, and [dataset](~dataset) exists, the series will use `dataset`. `datasetIndex` specifies which dataset will be used.

dataGroupId.desc:
A groupID common to all data in the series. the groupID will be used to classify the data and determine how merge and split animations are performed in the universal transition animation.

If you are using the [dataset](~dataset) component to represent the data, it is recommended to use `encode.itemGroupID` to specify which dimension is encoded as the groupID.

data.groupId.desc: The groupID of this data item. groupID will be used to classify the data.

data.selected.desc: Whether the data item is selected.

data.label.desc: The label configuration of a single sector.

data.label.position.desc:
The position of label.

**Options: **
+ `'outside'`

Outside of sectors of pie chart, which relates to corresponding sector through [visual guide line](~series-pie.labelLine).

+ `'inside'`

Inside the sectors of pie chart.

+ `'inner'` is the same with `'inside'`.
+ `'center'`

In the center of pie chart. See [pie-doughnut example](pie-doughnut)

data.label.rotate.desc:
Label rotation.

+ If `true`, layout label radically.
+ If `number`, means degree that labels are rotated. From -90 degree to 90 degree. The negative value represents clockwise.

data.label.borderColor.desc: Border color of the text fragment.

data.label.borderWidth.desc: Border width of the text fragment.

data.label.borderType.desc:
the text fragment border type.



Possible values are:
+ `'solid'`
+ `'dashed'`
+ `'dotted'`

Since `v5.0.0`, it can also be a number or a number array to specify the [dash array](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/SVG/Attribute/stroke-dasharray) of the line. With
`borderDashOffset`
, we can make the line style more flexible.

For example：
```js
{

borderType: [5, 10],

borderDashOffset: 5
}
```

data.label.borderDashOffset.desc:
> Since `v5.0.0`





To set the line dash offset. With
`borderType`
, we can make the line style more flexible.

Refer to MDN [lineDashOffset](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/lineDashOffset) for more details.

data.label.borderRadius.desc: Border radius of the text fragment.

data.label.padding.desc:
Padding of the text fragment, for example:

+ `padding: [3, 4, 5, 6]`: represents padding of `[top, right, bottom, left]`.
+ `padding: 4`: represents `padding: [4, 4, 4, 4]`.
+ `padding: [3, 4]`: represents `padding: [3, 4, 3, 4]`.

Notice, `width` and `height` specifies the width and height of the content, without `padding`.

data.label.shadowColor.desc: Shadow color of the text block.

data.label.shadowBlur.desc: Show blur of the text block.

data.label.shadowOffsetX.desc: Shadow X offset of the text block.

data.label.shadowOffsetY.desc: Shadow Y offset of the text block.

data.label.textBorderWidth.desc: Storke line width of the text.

data.label.overflow.desc:
Determine how to display the text when it's overflow. Available when `width` is set.

+ `'truncate'` Truncate the text and trailing with `ellipsis`.
+ `'break'` Break by word
+ `'breakAll'` Break by character.

data.label.ellipsis.desc: Ellipsis to be displayed when `overflow` is set to `truncate`.

data.label.lineOverflow.desc:
Determine how to display the text when it's overflow on height.

+ `'truncate'` Truncate the overflow lines.

Padding of the text fragment, for example:

data.label.rich.<style_name>.shadowOffse.desc: Shadow X offset of the text block.

data.label.rich.<style_name>.width.desc:
Width of the text block. It is the width of the text by default. In most cases, there is no need to specify it. You may want to use it in some cases like make simple table or using background image (see `backgroundColor`).

Notice, `width` and `height` specifies the width and height of the content, without `padding`.

`width` can also be percent string, like `'100%'`, which represents the percent of `contentWidth` (that is, the width without `padding`) of its container box. It is based on `contentWidth` because that each text fragment is layout based on the `content box`, where it makes no sense that calculating width based on `outerWith` in prectice.


Notice, `width` and `height` only work when `rich` specified.

data.label.rich.<style_name>.height.desc:
Height of the text block. It is the width of the text by default. You may want to use it in some cases like using background image (see `backgroundColor`).

Notice, `width` and `height` specifies the width and height of the content, without `padding`.

Notice, `width` and `height` only work when `rich` specified.

data.itemStyle.shadowColor.desc: Shadow color. Support same format as `color`.

data.itemStyle.shadowOffsetY.desc: Offset distance on the vertical direction of shadow.

data.itemStyle.opacity.desc: Opacity of the component. Supports value from 0 to 1, and the component will not be drawn when set to 0.

data.itemStyle.decal.desc:
The style of the decal pattern. It works only if [aria.enabled](~aria.enabled) and [aria.decal.show](~aria.decal.show) are both set to be `true`.

If it is set to be `'none'`, no decal will be used.

data.itemStyle.decal.symbol.desc:
The symbol type of the decal. If it is in the type of `string[]`, it means the symbols are used one by one.



Icon types provided by ECharts includes



`'circle'`, `'rect'`, `'roundRect'`, `'triangle'`, `'diamond'`, `'pin'`, `'arrow'`, `'none'`







It can be set to an image with `'image://url'` , in which URL is the link to an image, or `dataURI` of an image.


An image URL example:

```
'image://http://xxx.xxx.xxx/a/b.png'
```

A `dataURI` example:

```
'image://data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhEAAQAMQAAORHHOVSKudfOulrSOp3WOyDZu6QdvCchPGolfO0o/XBs/fNwfjZ0frl3/zy7////wAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAACH5BAkAABAALAAAAAAQABAAAAVVICSOZGlCQAosJ6mu7fiyZeKqNKToQGDsM8hBADgUXoGAiqhSvp5QAnQKGIgUhwFUYLCVDFCrKUE1lBavAViFIDlTImbKC5Gm2hB0SlBCBMQiB0UjIQA7'
```



Icons can be set to arbitrary vector path via `'path://'` in ECharts. As compared with a raster image, vector paths prevent jagging and blurring when scaled, and have better control over changing colors. The size of the vector icon will be adapted automatically. Refer to [SVG PathData](http://www.w3.org/TR/SVG/paths.html#PathData) for more information about the format of the path. You may export vector paths from tools like Adobe

For example:

```
'path://M30.9,53.2C16.8,53.2,5.3,41.7,5.3,27.6S16.8,2,30.9,2C45,2,56.4,13.5,56.4,27.6S45,53.2,30.9,53.2z M30.9,3.5C17.6,3.5,6.8,14.4,6.8,27.6c0,13.3,10.8,24.1,24.101,24.1C44.2,51.7,55,40.9,55,27.6C54.9,14.4,44.1,3.5,30.9,3.5z M36.9,35.8c0,0.601-0.4,1-0.9,1h-1.3c-0.5,0-0.9-0.399-0.9-1V19.5c0-0.6,0.4-1,0.9-1H36c0.5,0,0.9,0.4,0.9,1V35.8z M27.8,35.8 c0,0.601-0.4,1-0.9,1h-1.3c-0.5,0-0.9-0.399-0.9-1V19.5c0-0.6,0.4-1,0.9-1H27c0.5,0,0.9,0.4,0.9,1L27.8,35.8L27.8,35.8z'
```

data.itemStyle.decal.symbolSize.desc: Range of values: `0` to `1`, representing the size of symbol relative to decal.

data.itemStyle.decal.symbolKeepAspect.desc: Whether or not to keep the aspect ratio of the pattern.

data.itemStyle.decal.color.desc: For the color of the decal pattern, it is recommended to use a translucent color, which can be superimposed on the color of the series itself.

data.itemStyle.decal.backgroundColor.desc: The background color of the decal will be over the color of the series itself, under the decal pattern.

data.itemStyle.decal.dashArrayX.desc:
The basic pattern of the decal pattern is an infinite loop in the form of `Pattern - Blank - Pattern - Blank - Pattern - Blank` both horizontally and vertically, respectively. By setting the length of each pattern and blank, complex pattern effects can be achieved.

`dashArrayX` controls the horizontal pattern pattern. When its value is of type `number` or `number[]`, it is similar to [SVG stroke-dasharray](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/SVG/Attribute/stroke-dasharray).

- If it is of type `number`, it means that the pattern and the blank space are of this value respectively. For example, `5` means the pattern with width 5 is displayed first, then 5 pixels empty, then the pattern with width 5 is displayed...

- In the case of `number[]` type, it means that the pattern and empty space are loops of an array of values. For example: `[5, 10, 2, 6]` means the pattern is 5 pixels wide, then 10 pixels empty, then the pattern is 2 pixels wide, then 6 pixels empty, then the pattern is 5 pixels wide...

- If of type `(number | number[])[]`, it means that each row is a loop with an array of values for the pattern and blank space. For example: `[10, [2, 5]]` means that the first line will be 10 pixels by 10 pixels and empty space, the second line will be 2 pixels by 2 pixels and empty space, and the third line will be 10 pixels by 10 pixels and empty space...

This interface can be better understood with the following examples.

~[700x300](doc-example/aria-decal&edit=1&reset=1)

data.itemStyle.decal.dashArrayY.desc:
The basic pattern of the decal pattern is an infinite loop in the form of `Pattern - Blank - Pattern - Blank - Pattern - Blank` both horizontally and vertically, respectively. By setting the length of each pattern and blank, complex pattern effects can be achieved.

`dashArrayY` controls the horizontal pattern pattern. Similar to [SVG stroke-dasharray](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/SVG/Attribute/stroke-dasharray).

- If it is a `number` type, it means the pattern and the blank are each of this value. For example, `5` means that the pattern with a height of 5 is displayed first, then 5 pixels empty, then the pattern with a height of 5 is displayed...

- In the case of `number[]` type, it means that the pattern and empty space are loops of sequential array values. For example: `[5, 10, 2, 6]` means the pattern is 5 pixels high, then 10 pixels empty, then the pattern is 2 pixels high, then 6 pixels empty, then the pattern is 5 pixels high...

This interface can be better understood with the following examples.

~[700x300](doc-example/aria-decal&edit=1&reset=1)

data.itemStyle.decal.rotation.desc: The overall rotation angle (in radians) of the pattern, in the range from `-Math.

data.itemStyle.decal.maxTileWidth.desc: The upper limit of the width of the generated pattern before it is duplicated. Usually this value is not necessary, but you can try to increase it if you notice discontinuous seams in the pattern when it repeats.

data.itemStyle.decal.maxTileHeight.desc: The upper limit of the height of the generated pattern before it repeats. This value is usually not necessary to set, but you can try to increase it if you find that the pattern has discontinuous seams when it is repeated.

data.itemStyle.borderRadius.desc:
> Since `v5.0.0`



To specify the roundness for corners of the sectors of the pie chart. It can be either a specific pixel value or a percentage value relative to the radius of the sector.

+ `borderRadius: 10`: means that both inner corner radius and outer corner radius are `10px`.
+ `borderRadius: '20%'`: means that both inner corner radius is `20%` of the inner radius of the pie and outer corner radius is `20%` of the outer radius of the pie.
+ `borderRadius: [10, 20]`: means that the inner corner radius is `10px` and the outer corner radius is `20px`.
+ `borderRadius: ['20%', '50%']`: means that the inner corner radius is `20%` of the inner radius of the pie and the outer corner radius is `50%` of the outer radius of the pie.

data.emphasis.label.rotate.desc:
Label rotation.

+ If `true`, layout label radically.
+ If `number`, means degree that labels are rotated. From -90 degree to 90 degree. The negative value represents clockwise.

data.emphasis.label.borderColor.desc: Border color of the text fragment.

data.emphasis.label.borderWidth.desc: Border width of the text fragment.

data.emphasis.label.borderType.desc:
the text fragment border type.



Possible values are:
+ `'solid'`
+ `'dashed'`
+ `'dotted'`

Since `v5.0.0`, it can also be a number or a number array to specify the [dash array](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/SVG/Attribute/stroke-dasharray) of the line. With
`borderDashOffset`
, we can make the line style more flexible.

For example：
```js
{

borderType: [5, 10],

borderDashOffset: 5
}
```

data.emphasis.label.rich.<style_name>.wi.desc:
Width of the text block. It is the width of the text by default. In most cases, there is no need to specify it. You may want to use it in some cases like make simple table or using background image (see `backgroundColor`).

Notice, `width` and `height` specifies the width and height of the content, without `padding`.

`width` can also be percent string, like `'100%'`, which represents the percent of `contentWidth` (that is, the width without `padding`) of its container box. It is based on `contentWidth` because that each text fragment is layout based on the `content box`, where it makes no sense that calculating width based on `outerWith` in prectice.


Notice, `width` and `height` only work when `rich` specified.

data.emphasis.labelLine.lineStyle.type.desc:
line type.


Possible values are:

+ `'dashed'`
+ `'dotted'`

`type`
, we can make the line style more flexible.

Refer to MDN [lineDashOffset](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/lineDashOffset) for more details.

data.emphasis.labelLine.lineStyle.cap.desc:
> Since `v5.0.0`





To specify how to draw the end points of the line.
Possible values are:
+ `'butt'`: The ends of lines are squared off at the endpoints.
+ `'round'`: The ends of lines are rounded.
+ `'square'`: The ends of lines are squared off by adding a box with an equal width and half the height of the line's thickness.

Default value is `'butt'`. Refer to MDN [lineCap](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/lineCap) for more details.

data.emphasis.labelLine.lineStyle.join.desc:
> Since `v5.0.0`





To determine the shape used to join two line segments where they meet.

Possible values are:
+ `'bevel'`: Fills an additional triangular area between the common endpoint of connected segments, and the separate outside rectangular corners of each segment.
+ `'round'`: Rounds off the corners of a shape by filling an additional sector of disc centered at the common endpoint of connected segments. The radius for these rounded corners is equal to the line width.
+ `'miter'`: Connected segments are joined by extending their outside edges to connect at a single point, with the effect of filling an additional lozenge-shaped area. This setting is affected by the
`miterLimit`
property.

Default value is `'bevel'`. Refer to MDN [lineJoin](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/lineJoin) for more details.

data.emphasis.labelLine.lineStyle.miterL.desc:
> Since `v5.0.0`





To set the miter limit ratio. Only works when
`join`
is set as `miter`.

Default value is `10`. Negative、`0`、`Infinity` and `NaN` values are ignored.

Refer to MDN [miterLimit](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/miterLimit) for more details.

data.emphasis.labelLine.lineStyle.shadow.desc:
Size of shadow blur. This attribute should be used along with `shadowColor`,`shadowOffsetX`, `shadowOffsetY` to set shadow to component.

For example:
```js
{
shadowColor: 'rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.5)',
shadowBlur: 10
}
```
Shadow color. Support same format as `color`.
Offset distance on the horizontal direction of shadow.
Offset distance on the vertical direction of shadow.

data.emphasis.labelLine.lineStyle.opacit.desc: Opacity of the component. Supports value from 0 to 1, and the component will not be drawn when set to 0.

data.emphasis.itemStyle.color.desc:

data.blur.itemStyle.borderCap.desc:
> Since `v5.0.0`





To specify how to draw the end points of the line.
Possible values are:
+ `'butt'`: The ends of lines are squared off at the endpoints.
+ `'round'`: The ends of lines are rounded.
+ `'square'`: The ends of lines are squared off by adding a box with an equal width and half the height of the line's thickness.

Default value is `'butt'`. Refer to MDN [lineCap](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/lineCap) for more details.

data.blur.itemStyle.borderJoin.desc:

Possible values are:
+ `'bevel'`: Fills an additional triangular area between the common endpoint of connected segments, and the separate outside rectangular corners of each segment.
+ `'round'`: Rounds off the corners of a shape by filling an additional sector of disc centered at the common endpoint of connected segments. The radius for these rounded corners is equal to the line width.
+ `'miter'`: Connected segments are joined by extending their outside edges to connect at a single point, with the effect of filling an additional lozenge-shaped area. This setting is affected by the
`borderMiterLimit`
property.

Default value is `'bevel'`. Refer to MDN [lineJoin](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/lineJoin) for more details.

data.blur.itemStyle.borderRadius.desc:
> Since `v5.0.0`



To specify the roundness for corners of the sectors of the pie chart. It can be either a specific pixel value or a percentage value relative to the radius of the sector.

+ `borderRadius: 10`: means that both inner corner radius and outer corner radius are `10px`.
+ `borderRadius: '20%'`: means that both inner corner radius is `20%` of the inner radius of the pie and outer corner radius is `20%` of the outer radius of the pie.
+ `borderRadius: [10, 20]`: means that the inner corner radius is `10px` and the outer corner radius is `20px`.
+ `borderRadius: ['20%', '50%']`: means that the inner corner radius is `20%` of the inner radius of the pie and the outer corner radius is `50%` of the outer radius of the pie.

data.select.label.rich.<style_name>.widt.desc:
Width of the text block. It is the width of the text by default. In most cases, there is no need to specify it. You may want to use it in some cases like make simple table or using background image (see `backgroundColor`).

Notice, `width` and `height` specifies the width and height of the content, without `padding`.

`width` can also be percent string, like `'100%'`, which represents the percent of `contentWidth` (that is, the width without `padding`) of its container box. It is based on `contentWidth` because that each text fragment is layout based on the `content box`, where it makes no sense that calculating width based on `outerWith` in prectice.


Notice, `width` and `height` only work when `rich` specified.

data.select.label.rich.<style_name>.heig.desc:
Height of the text block. It is the width of the text by default. You may want to use it in some cases like using background image (see `backgroundColor`).

> **Notice：**series.data.tooltip only works when [tooltip.trigger](~tooltip.trigger) is `'item'`.
The position of the tooltip's floating layer, which would follow the position of mouse by default. Options: + `Array` Display the position of tooltip's floating layer through array, which supports absolute position and relative percentage. Example: ```js // absolute position, which is 10px to the left side and 10px to the top side of the container position: [10, 10] // relative position, in the exact center of the container position: ['50%', '50%'] ``` + `Function` Callback function in the following form: ```js (point: Array, params: Object|Array.
