markPoint.symbol.desc:
Symbol of .



Icon types provided by ECharts includes



`'circle'`, `'rect'`, `'roundRect'`, `'triangle'`, `'diamond'`, `'pin'`, `'arrow'`, `'none'`







It can be set to an image with `'image://url'` , in which URL is the link to an image, or `dataURI` of an image.


An image URL example:

```
'image://http://xxx.xxx.xxx/a/b.png'
```

A `dataURI` example:

```
'image://data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhEAAQAMQAAORHHOVSKudfOulrSOp3WOyDZu6QdvCchPGolfO0o/XBs/fNwfjZ0frl3/zy7////wAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAACH5BAkAABAALAAAAAAQABAAAAVVICSOZGlCQAosJ6mu7fiyZeKqNKToQGDsM8hBADgUXoGAiqhSvp5QAnQKGIgUhwFUYLCVDFCrKUE1lBavAViFIDlTImbKC5Gm2hB0SlBCBMQiB0UjIQA7'
```



Icons can be set to arbitrary vector path via `'path://'` in ECharts. As compared with a raster image, vector paths prevent jagging and blurring when scaled, and have better control over changing colors. The size of the vector icon will be adapted automatically. Refer to [SVG PathData](http://www.w3.org/TR/SVG/paths.html#PathData) for more information about the format of the path. You may export vector paths from tools like Adobe

For example:

```
'path://M30.9,53.2C16.8,53.2,5.3,41.7,5.3,27.6S16.8,2,30.9,2C45,2,56.4,13.5,56.4,27.6S45,53.2,30.9,53.2z M30.9,3.5C17.6,3.5,6.8,14.4,6.8,27.6c0,13.3,10.8,24.1,24.101,24.1C44.2,51.7,55,40.9,55,27.6C54.9,14.4,44.1,3.5,30.9,3.5z M36.9,35.8c0,0.601-0.4,1-0.9,1h-1.3c-0.5,0-0.9-0.399-0.9-1V19.5c0-0.6,0.4-1,0.9-1H36c0.5,0,0.9,0.4,0.9,1V35.8z M27.8,35.8 c0,0.601-0.4,1-0.9,1h-1.3c-0.5,0-0.9-0.399-0.9-1V19.5c0-0.6,0.4-1,0.9-1H27c0.5,0,0.9,0.4,0.9,1L27.8,35.8L27.8,35.8z'
```












If symbols needs to be different, you can set with callback function in the following format:
```js
(value: Array|number, params: Object) => string
```
The first parameter `value` is the value in [data](~series-pie.data), and the second parameter `params` is the rest parameters of data item.

markPoint.symbolSize.desc:
symbol size. It can be set to single numbers like `10`, or use an array to represent width and height. For example, `[20, 10]` means symbol width is `20`, and height is`10`.


If size of symbols needs to be different, you can set with callback function in the following format:
```js
(value: Array|number, params: Object) => number|Array
```
The first parameter `value` is the value in [data](~series-pie.data), and the second parameter `params` is the rest parameters of data item.

markPoint.symbolRotate.desc:
Rotate degree of  symbol. The negative value represents clockwise. Note that when `symbol` is set to be `'arrow'` in `markLine`, `symbolRotate` value will be ignored, and compulsively use tangent angle.


If rotation of symbols needs to be different, you can set with callback function in the following format:
```js
(value: Array|number, params: Object) => number
```
The first parameter `value` is the value in [data](~series-pie.data), and the second parameter `params` is the rest parameters of data item.
> Callback is supported since 4.8.0 .

markPoint.symbolKeepAspect.desc: Whether to keep aspect for symbols in the form of `path://`.

markPoint.symbolOffset.desc:
Offset of  symbol relative to original position. By default, symbol will be put in the center position of data. But if symbol is from user-defined vector path or image, you may not expect symbol to be in center. In this case, you may use this attribute to set offset to default position. It can be in absolute pixel value, or in relative percentage value.

For example, `[0, '-50%']` means to move upside side position of symbol height. It can be used to make the arrow in the bottom to be at data position when symbol is pin.

markPoint.silent.desc: Whether to ignore mouse events. Default value is false, for triggering and responding to mouse events.

markPoint.label.position.desc:
Label position.

**Followings are the options: **

+ [x, y]

Use relative percentage, or absolute pixel values to represent position of label relative to top-left corner of bounding box.
For example:
```js
// Absolute pixel values
position: [10, 10],
// Relative percentage
position: ['50%', '50%']
```

+ 'top'
+ 'left'
+ 'right'
+ 'bottom'
+ 'inside'
+ 'insideLeft'
+ 'insideRight'
+ 'insideTop'
+ 'insideBottom'
+ 'insideTopLeft'
+ 'insideBottomLeft'
+ 'insideTopRight'
+ 'insideBottomRight'

See: [label position](doc-example/label-position).

markPoint.label.distance.desc:
Distance to the host graphic element.


It is valid only when `position` is string value (like `'top'`、`'insideRight'`).

See: [label position](doc-example/label-position).

markPoint.label.rotate.desc:
Rotate label, from -90 degree to 90, positive value represents rotate anti-clockwise.

See: [label rotation](bar-label-rotation).

markPoint.label.offset.desc: Whether to move text slightly. For example: `[30, 40]` means move `30` horizontally and move `40` vertically.

markPoint.label.color.desc:
text color.




If set as `'inherit'`, the color will assigned as visual color, such as series color.

markPoint.label.borderColor.desc:
Border color of the text fragment.




If set as `'inherit'`, the color will assigned as visual color, such as series color.

markPoint.label.borderWidth.desc: Border width of the text fragment.

markPoint.label.borderType.desc:
the text fragment border type.



Possible values are:
+ `'solid'`
+ `'dashed'`
+ `'dotted'`

Since `v5.0.0`, it can also be a number or a number array to specify the [dash array](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/SVG/Attribute/stroke-dasharray) of the line. With
`borderDashOffset`
, we can make the line style more flexible.

For example：
```js
{

borderType: [5, 10],

borderDashOffset: 5
}
```

markPoint.label.borderDashOffset.desc:
> Since `v5.0.0`





To set the line dash offset. With
`borderType`
, we can make the line style more flexible.

Refer to MDN [lineDashOffset](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/lineDashOffset) for more details.

markPoint.label.borderRadius.desc: Border radius of the text fragment.

markPoint.label.padding.desc:
Padding of the text fragment, for example:

+ `padding: [3, 4, 5, 6]`: represents padding of `[top, right, bottom, left]`.
+ `padding: 4`: represents `padding: [4, 4, 4, 4]`.
+ `padding: [3, 4]`: represents `padding: [3, 4, 3, 4]`.

Notice, `width` and `height` specifies the width and height of the content, without `padding`.

markPoint.label.shadowColor.desc: Shadow color of the text block.

markPoint.label.shadowBlur.desc: Show blur of the text block.

markPoint.label.shadowOffsetX.desc: Shadow X offset of the text block.

markPoint.label.shadowOffsetY.desc: Shadow Y offset of the text block.

markPoint.label.textBorderColor.desc:
Storke color of the text.




If set as `'inherit'`, the color will assigned as visual color, such as series color.

markPoint.label.textBorderWidth.desc: Storke line width of the text.

markPoint.label.textBorderType.desc:

markPoint.label.overflow.desc:
Determine how to display the text when it's overflow. Available when `width` is set.

+ `'truncate'` Truncate the text and trailing with `ellipsis`.
+ `'break'` Break by word
+ `'breakAll'` Break by character.

markPoint.label.ellipsis.desc: Ellipsis to be displayed when `overflow` is set to `truncate`.

markPoint.label.lineOverflow.desc:
Determine how to display the text when it's overflow on height.

+ `'truncate'` Truncate the overflow lines.

markPoint.label.rich.<style_name>.width.desc:
Width of the text block. It is the width of the text by default. In most cases, there is no need to specify it. You may want to use it in some cases like make simple table or using background image (see `backgroundColor`).

Notice, `width` and `height` specifies the width and height of the content, without `padding`.

`width` can also be percent string, like `'100%'`, which represents the percent of `contentWidth` (that is, the width without `padding`) of its container box. It is based on `contentWidth` because that each text fragment is layout based on the `content box`, where it makes no sense that calculating width based on `outerWith` in prectice.


Notice, `width` and `height` only work when `rich` specified.

markPoint.label.rich.<style_name>.height.desc:
Height of the text block. It is the width of the text by default. You may want to use it in some cases like using background image (see `backgroundColor`).

Notice, `width` and `height` specifies the width and height of the content, without `padding`.

Notice, `width` and `height` only work when `rich` specified.

markPoint.itemStyle.borderColor.desc: border color, whose format is similar to that of `color`.

markPoint.itemStyle.borderWidth.desc:
border width. No border when it is set to be 0.

(${name} ? ${name} : "") + " border width. No border when it is set to be 0."

markPoint.itemStyle.borderType.desc:
border type.



Possible values are:
+ `'solid'`
+ `'dashed'`
+ `'dotted'`

Since `v5.0.0`, it can also be a number or a number array to specify the [dash array](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/SVG/Attribute/stroke-dasharray) of the line. With
`borderDashOffset`

markPoint.itemStyle.borderDashOffset.desc:
> Since `v5.0.0`





To set the line dash offset. With
`borderType`

Refer to MDN [lineDashOffset](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/lineDashOffset) for more details.

markPoint.itemStyle.borderCap.desc:
> Since `v5.0.0`





To specify how to draw the end points of the line.
Possible values are:
+ `'butt'`: The ends of lines are squared off at the endpoints.
+ `'round'`: The ends of lines are rounded.
+ `'square'`: The ends of lines are squared off by adding a box with an equal width and half the height of the line's thickness.

Default value is `'butt'`. Refer to MDN [lineCap](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/lineCap) for more details.

markPoint.itemStyle.borderJoin.desc:
> Since `v5.0.0`





To determine the shape used to join two line segments where they meet.

Possible values are:
+ `'bevel'`: Fills an additional triangular area between the common endpoint of connected segments, and the separate outside rectangular corners of each segment.
+ `'round'`: Rounds off the corners of a shape by filling an additional sector of disc centered at the common endpoint of connected segments. The radius for these rounded corners is equal to the line width.
+ `'miter'`: Connected segments are joined by extending their outside edges to connect at a single point, with the effect of filling an additional lozenge-shaped area. This setting is affected by the
`borderMiterLimit`
property.

Default value is `'bevel'`. Refer to MDN [lineJoin](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/lineJoin) for more details.

markPoint.itemStyle.borderMiterLimit.desc:
> Since `v5.0.0`





To set the miter limit ratio. Only works when
`borderJoin`
is set as `miter`.

Default value is `10`. Negative、`0`、`Infinity` and `NaN` values are ignored.

Refer to MDN [miterLimit](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/miterLimit) for more details.

markPoint.itemStyle.shadowBlur.desc:
Size of shadow blur. This attribute should be used along with `shadowColor`,`shadowOffsetX`, `shadowOffsetY` to set shadow to component.

For example:
```js
{
shadowColor: 'rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.5)',
shadowBlur: 10
}
```

markPoint.itemStyle.opacity.desc: Opacity of the component. Supports value from 0 to 1, and the component will not be drawn when set to 0.

markPoint.emphasis.itemStyle.borderCap.desc:
> Since `v5.0.0`





To specify how to draw the end points of the line.
Possible values are:
+ `'butt'`: The ends of lines are squared off at the endpoints.
+ `'round'`: The ends of lines are rounded.
+ `'square'`: The ends of lines are squared off by adding a box with an equal width and half the height of the line's thickness.

Default value is `'butt'`. Refer to MDN [lineCap](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/lineCap) for more details.

markPoint.emphasis.itemStyle.borderJoin.desc:
> Since `v5.0.0`





To determine the shape used to join two line segments where they meet.

Possible values are:
+ `'bevel'`: Fills an additional triangular area between the common endpoint of connected segments, and the separate outside rectangular corners of each segment.
+ `'round'`: Rounds off the corners of a shape by filling an additional sector of disc centered at the common endpoint of connected segments. The radius for these rounded corners is equal to the line width.
+ `'miter'`: Connected segments are joined by extending their outside edges to connect at a single point, with the effect of filling an additional lozenge-shaped area. This setting is affected by the
`borderMiterLimit`
property.

Default value is `'bevel'`. Refer to MDN [lineJoin](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/lineJoin) for more details.

markPoint.emphasis.itemStyle.borderMiter.desc:
> Since `v5.0.0`





To set the miter limit ratio. Only works when
`borderJoin`
is set as `miter`.

Default value is `10`. Negative、`0`、`Infinity` and `NaN` values are ignored.

Refer to MDN [miterLimit](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/miterLimit) for more details.

markPoint.emphasis.itemStyle.shadowBlur.desc:
Size of shadow blur. This attribute should be used along with `shadowColor`,`shadowOffsetX`, `shadowOffsetY` to set shadow to component.

For example:
```js
{
shadowColor: 'rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.5)',
shadowBlur: 10
}
```

markPoint.emphasis.itemStyle.shadowColor.desc: Shadow color. Support same format as `color`.

markPoint.emphasis.itemStyle.shadowOffse.desc: Offset distance on the horizontal direction of shadow.
Offset distance on the vertical direction of shadow.

markPoint.emphasis.itemStyle.opacity.desc: Opacity of the component. Supports value from 0 to 1, and the component will not be drawn when set to 0.

markPoint.blur.desc:
> Since `v5.0.0`



Configurations of blur state. Whether to blur follows the series.

markPoint.blur.label.position.desc:
Label position.

**Followings are the options: **

+ [x, y]

Use relative percentage, or absolute pixel values to represent position of label relative to top-left corner of bounding box.
For example:
```js
// Absolute pixel values
position: [10, 10],
// Relative percentage
position: ['50%', '50%']
```

+ 'top'
+ 'left'
+ 'right'
+ 'bottom'
+ 'inside'
+ 'insideLeft'
+ 'insideRight'
+ 'insideTop'
+ 'insideBottom'
+ 'insideTopLeft'
+ 'insideBottomLeft'
+ 'insideTopRight'
+ 'insideBottomRight'

See: [label position](doc-example/label-position).

markPoint.blur.label.distance.desc:

See: [label position](doc-example/label-position).

markPoint.blur.label.rotate.desc:
Rotate label, from -90 degree to 90, positive value represents rotate anti-clockwise.

See: [label rotation](bar-label-rotation).

markPoint.blur.label.offset.desc: Whether to move text slightly. For example: `[30, 40]` means move `30` horizontally and move `40` vertically.

markPoint.blur.label.color.desc:
text color.




If set as `'inherit'`, the color will assigned as visual color, such as series color.

markPoint.blur.label.borderColor.desc:

markPoint.blur.label.borderWidth.desc: Border width of the text fragment.

markPoint.blur.label.borderType.desc:
the text fragment border type.



Possible values are:
+ `'solid'`
+ `'dashed'`
+ `'dotted'`

Since `v5.0.0`, it can also be a number or a number array to specify the [dash array](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/SVG/Attribute/stroke-dasharray) of the line. With
`borderDashOffset`
, we can make the line style more flexible.

For example：

```js
}
```

+ `padding: 4`: represents `padding: [4, 4, 4, 4]`.
+ `padding: [3, 4]`: represents `padding: [3, 4, 3, 4]`.

Notice, `width` and `height` specifies the width and height of the content, without `padding`.

markPoint.blur.label.overflow.desc:

markPoint.blur.label.lineOverflow.desc:

markPoint.blur.label.rich.<style_name>.w.desc:
Width of the text block. It is the width of the text by default. In most cases, there is no need to specify it. You may want to use it in some cases like make simple table or using background image (see `backgroundColor`).

Notice, `width` and `height` specifies the width and height of the content, without `padding`.

`width` can also be percent string, like `'100%'`, which represents the percent of `contentWidth` (that is, the width without `padding`) of its container box. It is based on `contentWidth` because that each text fragment is layout based on the `content box`, where it makes no sense that calculating width based on `outerWith` in prectice.


Notice, `width` and `height` only work when `rich` specified.

markPoint.blur.label.rich.<style_name>.h.desc:

markPoint.data.desc:
Data array for mark points, each of which is an object. Here are some ways to assign mark point position.
1. Assign coordinate according to container with [x](~series-pie.markPoint.data.x), [y](~series-pie.markPoint.data.y) attribute, in which pixel values and percentage are supported.



When multiple attributes exist, priority is as the above order.

**For example: **
```js
data: [

{
name: 'screen coordinate',
x: 100,
y: 100
}
]
```

markPoint.data.x.desc: X position according to container, in pixel.

markPoint.data.y.desc: Y position according to container, in pixel.

markPoint.data.value.desc: Label value, which can be ignored.

markPoint.data.symbol.desc:
Symbol of .



Icon types provided by ECharts includes



`'circle'`, `'rect'`, `'roundRect'`, `'triangle'`, `'diamond'`, `'pin'`, `'arrow'`, `'none'`







It can be set to an image with `'image://url'` , in which URL is the link to an image, or `dataURI` of an image.


An image URL example:

```
'image://http://xxx.xxx.xxx/a/b.png'
```

A `dataURI` example:

```
'image://data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhEAAQAMQAAORHHOVSKudfOulrSOp3WOyDZu6QdvCchPGolfO0o/XBs/fNwfjZ0frl3/zy7////wAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAACH5BAkAABAALAAAAAAQABAAAAVVICSOZGlCQAosJ6mu7fiyZeKqNKToQGDsM8hBADgUXoGAiqhSvp5QAnQKGIgUhwFUYLCVDFCrKUE1lBavAViFIDlTImbKC5Gm2hB0SlBCBMQiB0UjIQA7'
```



Icons can be set to arbitrary vector path via `'path://'` in ECharts. As compared with a raster image, vector paths prevent jagging and blurring when scaled, and have better control over changing colors. The size of the vector icon will be adapted automatically. Refer to [SVG PathData](http://www.w3.org/TR/SVG/paths.html#PathData) for more information about the format of the path. You may export vector paths from tools like Adobe

For example:

```
'path://M30.9,53.2C16.8,53.2,5.3,41.7,5.3,27.6S16.8,2,30.9,2C45,2,56.4,13.5,56.4,27.6S45,53.2,30.9,53.2z M30.9,3.5C17.6,3.5,6.8,14.4,6.8,27.6c0,13.3,10.8,24.1,24.101,24.1C44.2,51.7,55,40.9,55,27.6C54.9,14.4,44.1,3.5,30.9,3.5z M36.9,35.8c0,0.601-0.4,1-0.9,1h-1.3c-0.5,0-0.9-0.399-0.9-1V19.5c0-0.6,0.4-1,0.9-1H36c0.5,0,0.9,0.4,0.9,1V35.8z M27.8,35.8 c0,0.601-0.4,1-0.9,1h-1.3c-0.5,0-0.9-0.399-0.9-1V19.5c0-0.6,0.4-1,0.9-1H27c0.5,0,0.9,0.4,0.9,1L27.8,35.8L27.8,35.8z'
```

markPoint.data.symbolSize.desc: symbol size. It can be set to single numbers like `10`, or use an array to represent width and height. For example, `[20, 10]` means symbol width is `20`, and height is`10`.

markPoint.data.symbolRotate.desc: Rotate degree of  symbol. The negative value represents clockwise. Note that when `symbol` is set to be `'arrow'` in `markLine`, `symbolRotate` value will be ignored, and compulsively use tangent angle.

markPoint.data.symbolKeepAspect.desc: Whether to keep aspect for symbols in the form of `path://`.

markPoint.data.symbolOffset.desc:
Offset of  symbol relative to original position. By default, symbol will be put in the center position of data. But if symbol is from user-defined vector path or image, you may not expect symbol to be in center. In this case, you may use this attribute to set offset to default position. It can be in absolute pixel value, or in relative percentage value.

For example, `[0, '-50%']` means to move upside side position of symbol height. It can be used to make the arrow in the bottom to be at data position when symbol is pin.

Since `v5.0.0`, it can also be a number or a number array to specify the [dash array](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/SVG/Attribute/stroke-dasharray) of the line. With

```js
textBorderDashOffset: 5
}
```

markPoint.data.label.rich.<style_name>.w.desc:
Width of the text block. It is the width of the text by default. In most cases, there is no need to specify it. You may want to use it in some cases like make simple table or using background image (see `backgroundColor`).

Notice, `width` and `height` specifies the width and height of the content, without `padding`.

`width` can also be percent string, like `'100%'`, which represents the percent of `contentWidth` (that is, the width without `padding`) of its container box. It is based on `contentWidth` because that each text fragment is layout based on the `content box`, where it makes no sense that calculating width based on `outerWith` in prectice.


Notice, `width` and `height` only work when `rich` specified.

markPoint.data.label.rich.<style_name>.h.desc:

Notice, `width` and `height` only work when `rich` specified.

markPoint.data.emphasis.itemStyle.color.desc:
color.



> Supports setting as solid color using `rgb(255,255,255)`, `rgba(255,255,255,1)`, `#fff`, etc. Also supports setting as gradient color and pattern fill, see [option.color](~color) for details

markPoint.data.emphasis.itemStyle.border.desc: border color, whose format is similar to that of `color`.

border width. No border when it is set to be 0.

(${name} ? ${name} : "") + " border width. No border when it is set to be 0."

border type.



Possible values are:
+ `'solid'`
+ `'dashed'`
+ `'dotted'`

Since `v5.0.0`, it can also be a number or a number array to specify the [dash array](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/SVG/Attribute/stroke-dasharray) of the line. With
`borderDashOffset`
, we can make the line style more flexible.

For example：
```js
{

borderType: [5, 10],

borderDashOffset: 5
}
```

> Since `v5.0.0`





To set the line dash offset. With
`borderType`
, we can make the line style more flexible.

Refer to MDN [lineDashOffset](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/lineDashOffset) for more details.

> Since `v5.0.0`





To specify how to draw the end points of the line.
Possible values are:
+ `'butt'`: The ends of lines are squared off at the endpoints.
+ `'round'`: The ends of lines are rounded.
+ `'square'`: The ends of lines are squared off by adding a box with an equal width and half the height of the line's thickness.

Default value is `'butt'`. Refer to MDN [lineCap](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/lineCap) for more details.

> Since `v5.0.0`





To determine the shape used to join two line segments where they meet.

Possible values are:
+ `'bevel'`: Fills an additional triangular area between the common endpoint of connected segments, and the separate outside rectangular corners of each segment.
+ `'round'`: Rounds off the corners of a shape by filling an additional sector of disc centered at the common endpoint of connected segments. The radius for these rounded corners is equal to the line width.
+ `'miter'`: Connected segments are joined by extending their outside edges to connect at a single point, with the effect of filling an additional lozenge-shaped area. This setting is affected by the
`borderMiterLimit`
property.

Default value is `'bevel'`. Refer to MDN [lineJoin](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/lineJoin) for more details.

> Since `v5.0.0`





To set the miter limit ratio. Only works when
`borderJoin`
is set as `miter`.

Default value is `10`. Negative、`0`、`Infinity` and `NaN` values are ignored.

Refer to MDN [miterLimit](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/miterLimit) for more details.

```js
shadowBlur: 10
}
```

border color, whose format is similar to that of `color`.

(${name} ? ${name} : "") + " border width. No border when it is set to be 0."

border type.



Possible values are:
+ `'solid'`
+ `'dashed'`
+ `'dotted'`

Since `v5.0.0`, it can also be a number or a number array to specify the [dash array](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/SVG/Attribute/stroke-dasharray) of the line. With
`borderDashOffset`
, we can make the line style more flexible.

For example：
```js
{

borderType: [5, 10],

borderDashOffset: 5
}
```

> Since `v5.0.0`





To set the line dash offset. With
`borderType`
, we can make the line style more flexible.

Refer to MDN [lineDashOffset](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/lineDashOffset) for more details.

> Since `v5.0.0`





To specify how to draw the end points of the line.
Possible values are:
+ `'butt'`: The ends of lines are squared off at the endpoints.
+ `'round'`: The ends of lines are rounded.
+ `'square'`: The ends of lines are squared off by adding a box with an equal width and half the height of the line's thickness.

Default value is `'butt'`. Refer to MDN [lineCap](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/lineCap) for more details.

> Since `v5.0.0`





To determine the shape used to join two line segments where they meet.

Possible values are:
+ `'bevel'`: Fills an additional triangular area between the common endpoint of connected segments, and the separate outside rectangular corners of each segment.
+ `'round'`: Rounds off the corners of a shape by filling an additional sector of disc centered at the common endpoint of connected segments. The radius for these rounded corners is equal to the line width.
+ `'miter'`: Connected segments are joined by extending their outside edges to connect at a single point, with the effect of filling an additional lozenge-shaped area. This setting is affected by the
`borderMiterLimit`
property.

Default value is `'bevel'`. Refer to MDN [lineJoin](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/lineJoin) for more details.

> Since `v5.0.0`





To set the miter limit ratio. Only works when
`borderJoin`
is set as `miter`.

Default value is `10`. Negative、`0`、`Infinity` and `NaN` values are ignored.

Refer to MDN [miterLimit](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/miterLimit) for more details.

Size of shadow blur. This attribute should be used along with `shadowColor`,`shadowOffsetX`, `shadowOffsetY` to set shadow to component.

For example:
```js
{
shadowColor: 'rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.5)',
shadowBlur: 10
}
```
Shadow color. Support same format as `color`.

Opacity of the component. Supports value from 0 to 1, and the component will not be drawn when set to 0.

markLine.desc: Use a line in the chart to illustrate.

markLine.silent.desc: Whether to ignore mouse events. Default value is false, for triggering and responding to mouse events.

markLine.symbol.desc: Symbol type at the two ends of the mark line. It can be an array for two ends, or assigned seperately. See [data.symbol](~series-pie.markLine.data.0.symbol) for more format information.

markLine.symbolSize.desc:
Symbol size at the two ends of the mark line. It can be an array for two ends, or assigned seperately.

**Attention: ** You cannot assgin width and height seperately as normal `symbolSize`.

markLine.precision.desc: Precision of marking line value, which is useful when displaying average value mark line.

markLine.label.position.desc:
Positions of labels can be:
+ `'start'` starting point of the line.
+ `'middle'` middle point of the line.
+ `'end'` ending point of the line.

Since version 4.7.0, more label positions are supported: `'start'`, `'middle'`, `'end'`, `'insideStartTop'`, `'insideStartBottom'`, `'insideMiddleTop'`, `'insideMiddleBottom'`, `'insideEndTop'`, `'insideEndBottom'`.

`'insideMiddleBottom'` is the same as `'middle'`. Position is as the following chart.

The distance between labels and mark lines can be set with [label.distance](~series-.markLine.label.distance).

~[800x500](bar-markline&reset=1&edit=1)

markLine.label.distance.desc: The distance between labels and mark lines. If it's an array, then the first element is the horizontal distance, and the second element is the vertical distance. If it's a number, then the horizontal and vertical distances are the same.

markLine.label.rich.<style_name>.width.desc:
Width of the text block. It is the width of the text by default. In most cases, there is no need to specify it. You may want to use it in some cases like make simple table or using background image (see `backgroundColor`).

Notice, `width` and `height` specifies the width and height of the content, without `padding`.

`width` can also be percent string, like `'100%'`, which represents the percent of `contentWidth` (that is, the width without `padding`) of its container box. It is based on `contentWidth` because that each text fragment is layout based on the `content box`, where it makes no sense that calculating width based on `outerWith` in prectice.


Notice, `width` and `height` only work when `rich` specified.

```js
dashOffset: 5
}
```

markLine.emphasis.lineStyle.dashOffset.desc:
> Since `v5.0.0`





To set the line dash offset. With
`type`
, we can make the line style more flexible.

Refer to MDN [lineDashOffset](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/lineDashOffset) for more details.

markLine.emphasis.lineStyle.cap.desc:
> Since `v5.0.0`





To specify how to draw the end points of the line.
Possible values are:
+ `'butt'`: The ends of lines are squared off at the endpoints.
+ `'round'`: The ends of lines are rounded.
+ `'square'`: The ends of lines are squared off by adding a box with an equal width and half the height of the line's thickness.

Default value is `'butt'`. Refer to MDN [lineCap](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/lineCap) for more details.

markLine.emphasis.lineStyle.join.desc:
> Since `v5.0.0`





To determine the shape used to join two line segments where they meet.

Possible values are:
+ `'bevel'`: Fills an additional triangular area between the common endpoint of connected segments, and the separate outside rectangular corners of each segment.
+ `'round'`: Rounds off the corners of a shape by filling an additional sector of disc centered at the common endpoint of connected segments. The radius for these rounded corners is equal to the line width.
+ `'miter'`: Connected segments are joined by extending their outside edges to connect at a single point, with the effect of filling an additional lozenge-shaped area. This setting is affected by the
`miterLimit`
property.

Default value is `'bevel'`. Refer to MDN [lineJoin](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/lineJoin) for more details.

markLine.emphasis.lineStyle.miterLimit.desc:
> Since `v5.0.0`





To set the miter limit ratio. Only works when
`join`
is set as `miter`.

Default value is `10`. Negative、`0`、`Infinity` and `NaN` values are ignored.

Refer to MDN [miterLimit](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/miterLimit) for more details.

markLine.emphasis.lineStyle.shadowBlur.desc:
Size of shadow blur. This attribute should be used along with `shadowColor`,`shadowOffsetX`, `shadowOffsetY` to set shadow to component.

For example:
```js
{
shadowColor: 'rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.5)',
shadowBlur: 10
}
```

markLine.emphasis.lineStyle.shadowColor.desc: Shadow color. Support same format as `color`.

markLine.emphasis.lineStyle.shadowOffset.desc: Offset distance on the horizontal direction of shadow.
Offset distance on the vertical direction of shadow.

markLine.emphasis.lineStyle.opacity.desc: Opacity of the component. Supports value from 0 to 1, and the component will not be drawn when set to 0.

markLine.blur.desc:
> Since `v5.0.0`



Configurations of blur state. Whether to blur follows the series.

markLine.blur.label.position.desc:
Positions of labels can be:
+ `'start'` starting point of the line.
+ `'middle'` middle point of the line.
+ `'end'` ending point of the line.

Since version 4.7.0, more label positions are supported: `'start'`, `'middle'`, `'end'`, `'insideStartTop'`, `'insideStartBottom'`, `'insideMiddleTop'`, `'insideMiddleBottom'`, `'insideEndTop'`, `'insideEndBottom'`.

`'insideMiddleBottom'` is the same as `'middle'`. Position is as the following chart.

The distance between labels and mark lines can be set with [label.distance](~series-.markLine.label.distance).

~[800x500](bar-markline&reset=1&edit=1)

markLine.blur.label.distance.desc: The distance between labels and mark lines. If it's an array, then the first element is the horizontal distance, and the second element is the vertical distance. If it's a number, then the horizontal and vertical distances are the same.

markLine.blur.label.color.desc:
text color.




If set as `'inherit'`, the color will assigned as visual color, such as series color.

markLine.blur.label.borderColor.desc:
Border color of the text fragment.




If set as `'inherit'`, the color will assigned as visual color, such as series color.

markLine.blur.label.borderWidth.desc: Border width of the text fragment.

markLine.blur.label.borderType.desc:
the text fragment border type.



Possible values are:
+ `'solid'`
+ `'dashed'`
+ `'dotted'`

Since `v5.0.0`, it can also be a number or a number array to specify the [dash array](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/SVG/Attribute/stroke-dasharray) of the line. With
`borderDashOffset`
, we can make the line style more flexible.

For example：
```js
{

borderType: [5, 10],

borderDashOffset: 5
}
```

markLine.blur.label.borderRadius.desc: Border radius of the text fragment.

markLine.blur.label.padding.desc:
Padding of the text fragment, for example:

+ `padding: [3, 4, 5, 6]`: represents padding of `[top, right, bottom, left]`.
+ `padding: 4`: represents `padding: [4, 4, 4, 4]`.
+ `padding: [3, 4]`: represents `padding: [3, 4, 3, 4]`.

Notice, `width` and `height` specifies the width and height of the content, without `padding`.

markLine.blur.label.overflow.desc:
Determine how to display the text when it's overflow. Available when `width` is set.

+ `'truncate'` Truncate the text and trailing with `ellipsis`.
+ `'break'` Break by word
+ `'breakAll'` Break by character.

markLine.blur.label.ellipsis.desc: Ellipsis to be displayed when `overflow` is set to `truncate`.

markLine.blur.label.lineOverflow.desc:

+ `'truncate'` Truncate the overflow lines.

markLine.blur.label.rich.<style_name>.wi.desc:
Width of the text block. It is the width of the text by default. In most cases, there is no need to specify it. You may want to use it in some cases like make simple table or using background image (see `backgroundColor`).

Notice, `width` and `height` specifies the width and height of the content, without `padding`.

`width` can also be percent string, like `'100%'`, which represents the percent of `contentWidth` (that is, the width without `padding`) of its container box. It is based on `contentWidth` because that each text fragment is layout based on the `content box`, where it makes no sense that calculating width based on `outerWith` in prectice.


Notice, `width` and `height` only work when `rich` specified.

markLine.blur.label.rich.<style_name>.he.desc:

Notice, `width` and `height` only work when `rich` specified.

markLine.data.0.name.desc: Name of the marker, which will display as a label.

markLine.data.0.x.desc: X position according to container, in pixel.

markLine.data.0.y.desc: Y position according to container, in pixel.

markLine.data.0.xAxis.desc:
Markline at x at given value, which only works for single data item. Example:

```
data: [{
name: 'A vertical line with X valued 100',
xAxis: 100
}]
```

or if xAxis is in `'time'` type, it can be set as:

```
{
name: 'A vertical line with X valued "2020-01-01"',
xAxis: '2020-01-01'
}]
```

markLine.data.0.yAxis.desc:
Markline at y at given value, which only works for single data item. Example:

```
data: [{
name: 'A horizontal line with X valued 100',
yAxis: 100
}]
```

or if yAxis is in `'time'` type, it can be set as:

```
{
name: 'A horizontal line with Y valued "2020-01-01"',
yAxis: '2020-01-01'
}]
```

markLine.data.0.value.desc: Label value, which can be ignored.

markLine.data.0.symbol.desc:
Symbol of 0.



Icon types provided by ECharts includes



`'circle'`, `'rect'`, `'roundRect'`, `'triangle'`, `'diamond'`, `'pin'`, `'arrow'`, `'none'`







It can be set to an image with `'image://url'` , in which URL is the link to an image, or `dataURI` of an image.


An image URL example:

```
'image://http://xxx.xxx.xxx/a/b.png'
```

A `dataURI` example:

```
'image://data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhEAAQAMQAAORHHOVSKudfOulrSOp3WOyDZu6QdvCchPGolfO0o/XBs/fNwfjZ0frl3/zy7////wAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAACH5BAkAABAALAAAAAAQABAAAAVVICSOZGlCQAosJ6mu7fiyZeKqNKToQGDsM8hBADgUXoGAiqhSvp5QAnQKGIgUhwFUYLCVDFCrKUE1lBavAViFIDlTImbKC5Gm2hB0SlBCBMQiB0UjIQA7'
```



Icons can be set to arbitrary vector path via `'path://'` in ECharts. As compared with a raster image, vector paths prevent jagging and blurring when scaled, and have better control over changing colors. The size of the vector icon will be adapted automatically. Refer to [SVG PathData](http://www.w3.org/TR/SVG/paths.html#PathData) for more information about the format of the path. You may export vector paths from tools like Adobe

For example:

```
'path://M30.9,53.2C16.8,53.2,5.3,41.7,5.3,27.6S16.8,2,30.9,2C45,2,56.4,13.5,56.4,27.6S45,53.2,30.9,53.2z M30.9,3.5C17.6,3.5,6.8,14.4,6.8,27.6c0,13.3,10.8,24.1,24.101,24.1C44.2,51.7,55,40.9,55,27.6C54.9,14.4,44.1,3.5,30.9,3.5z M36.9,35.8c0,0.601-0.4,1-0.9,1h-1.3c-0.5,0-0.9-0.399-0.9-1V19.5c0-0.6,0.4-1,0.9-1H36c0.5,0,0.9,0.4,0.9,1V35.8z M27.8,35.8 c0,0.601-0.4,1-0.9,1h-1.3c-0.5,0-0.9-0.399-0.9-1V19.5c0-0.6,0.4-1,0.9-1H27c0.5,0,0.9,0.4,0.9,1L27.8,35.8L27.8,35.8z'
```

markLine.data.0.symbolSize.desc: 0 symbol size. It can be set to single numbers like `10`, or use an array to represent width and height. For example, `[20, 10]` means symbol width is `20`, and height is`10`.

markLine.data.0.symbolRotate.desc: Rotate degree of 0 symbol. The negative value represents clockwise. Note that when `symbol` is set to be `'arrow'` in `markLine`, `symbolRotate` value will be ignored, and compulsively use tangent angle.

markLine.data.0.symbolKeepAspect.desc: Whether to keep aspect for symbols in the form of `path://`.

markLine.data.0.symbolOffset.desc:
Offset of 0 symbol relative to original position. By default, symbol will be put in the center position of data. But if symbol is from user-defined vector path or image, you may not expect symbol to be in center. In this case, you may use this attribute to set offset to default position. It can be in absolute pixel value, or in relative percentage value.

For example, `[0, '-50%']` means to move upside side position of symbol height. It can be used to make the arrow in the bottom to be at data position when symbol is pin.

markLine.data.0.emphasis.lineStyle.color.desc:
Line color.





> Supports setting as solid color using `rgb(255,255,255)`, `rgba(255,255,255,1)`, `#fff`, etc. Also supports setting as gradient color and pattern fill, see [option.color](~color) for details

markLine.data.0.emphasis.lineStyle.type.desc:
line type.


Possible values are:
+ `'solid'`
+ `'dashed'`
+ `'dotted'`

Since `v5.0.0`, it can also be a number or a number array to specify the [dash array](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/SVG/Attribute/stroke-dasharray) of the line. With
`dashOffset`
, we can make the line style more flexible.

For example：
```js
{

type: [5, 10],

dashOffset: 5
}
```

markLine.data.0.emphasis.lineStyle.dashO.desc:
> Since `v5.0.0`





To set the line dash offset. With
`type`
, we can make the line style more flexible.

Refer to MDN [lineDashOffset](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/lineDashOffset) for more details.

markLine.data.0.emphasis.lineStyle.cap.desc:
> Since `v5.0.0`





To specify how to draw the end points of the line.
Possible values are:
+ `'butt'`: The ends of lines are squared off at the endpoints.
+ `'round'`: The ends of lines are rounded.
+ `'square'`: The ends of lines are squared off by adding a box with an equal width and half the height of the line's thickness.

Default value is `'butt'`. Refer to MDN [lineCap](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/lineCap) for more details.

markLine.data.0.emphasis.lineStyle.join.desc:
> Since `v5.0.0`





To determine the shape used to join two line segments where they meet.

Possible values are:
+ `'bevel'`: Fills an additional triangular area between the common endpoint of connected segments, and the separate outside rectangular corners of each segment.
+ `'round'`: Rounds off the corners of a shape by filling an additional sector of disc centered at the common endpoint of connected segments. The radius for these rounded corners is equal to the line width.
+ `'miter'`: Connected segments are joined by extending their outside edges to connect at a single point, with the effect of filling an additional lozenge-shaped area. This setting is affected by the
`miterLimit`
property.

Default value is `'bevel'`. Refer to MDN [lineJoin](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/lineJoin) for more details.

markLine.data.0.emphasis.lineStyle.miter.desc:
> Since `v5.0.0`





To set the miter limit ratio. Only works when
`join`
is set as `miter`.

Default value is `10`. Negative、`0`、`Infinity` and `NaN` values are ignored.

Refer to MDN [miterLimit](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/miterLimit) for more details.

markLine.data.0.emphasis.lineStyle.shado.desc:
Size of shadow blur. This attribute should be used along with `shadowColor`,`shadowOffsetX`, `shadowOffsetY` to set shadow to component.

For example:
```js
{
shadowColor: 'rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.5)',
shadowBlur: 10
}
```
Shadow color. Support same format as `color`.
Offset distance on the horizontal direction of shadow.
Offset distance on the vertical direction of shadow.

markLine.data.0.emphasis.lineStyle.opaci.desc: Opacity of the component. Supports value from 0 to 1, and the component will not be drawn when set to 0.

markLine.data.0.emphasis.lineStyle.curve.desc: Edge curvature, which supports value from 0 to 1. The larger the value, the greater the curvature.

markLine.data.0.emphasis.label.position.desc:
Positions of labels can be:
+ `'start'` starting point of the line.
+ `'middle'` middle point of the line.
+ `'end'` ending point of the line.

Since version 4.7.0, more label positions are supported: `'start'`, `'middle'`, `'end'`, `'insideStartTop'`, `'insideStartBottom'`, `'insideMiddleTop'`, `'insideMiddleBottom'`, `'insideEndTop'`, `'insideEndBottom'`.

`'insideMiddleBottom'` is the same as `'middle'`. Position is as the following chart.

The distance between labels and mark lines can be set with [label.distance](~series-.markLine.label.distance).

~[800x500](bar-markline&reset=1&edit=1)

markLine.data.0.emphasis.label.distance.desc: The distance between labels and mark lines. If it's an array, then the first element is the horizontal distance, and the second element is the vertical distance. If it's a number, then the horizontal and vertical distances are the same.

markLine.data.1.name.desc: Name of the marker, which will display as a label.

markLine.data.1.x.desc: X position according to container, in pixel.

markLine.data.1.y.desc: Y position according to container, in pixel.

markLine.data.1.xAxis.desc:
Markline at x at given value, which only works for single data item. Example:

```
data: [{
name: 'A vertical line with X valued 100',
xAxis: 100
}]
```

or if xAxis is in `'time'` type, it can be set as:

```
{
name: 'A vertical line with X valued "2020-01-01"',
xAxis: '2020-01-01'
}]
```

markLine.data.1.yAxis.desc:
Markline at y at given value, which only works for single data item. Example:

```
data: [{
name: 'A horizontal line with X valued 100',
yAxis: 100
}]
```

or if yAxis is in `'time'` type, it can be set as:

```
{
name: 'A horizontal line with Y valued "2020-01-01"',
yAxis: '2020-01-01'
}]
```

markLine.data.1.value.desc: Label value, which can be ignored.

markLine.data.1.symbol.desc:
Symbol of 1.



Icon types provided by ECharts includes



`'circle'`, `'rect'`, `'roundRect'`, `'triangle'`, `'diamond'`, `'pin'`, `'arrow'`, `'none'`







It can be set to an image with `'image://url'` , in which URL is the link to an image, or `dataURI` of an image.


An image URL example:

```
'image://http://xxx.xxx.xxx/a/b.png'
```

A `dataURI` example:

```
'image://data:image/gif;base64,R0lGODlhEAAQAMQAAORHHOVSKudfOulrSOp3WOyDZu6QdvCchPGolfO0o/XBs/fNwfjZ0frl3/zy7////wAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAACH5BAkAABAALAAAAAAQABAAAAVVICSOZGlCQAosJ6mu7fiyZeKqNKToQGDsM8hBADgUXoGAiqhSvp5QAnQKGIgUhwFUYLCVDFCrKUE1lBavAViFIDlTImbKC5Gm2hB0SlBCBMQiB0UjIQA7'
```



Icons can be set to arbitrary vector path via `'path://'` in ECharts. As compared with a raster image, vector paths prevent jagging and blurring when scaled, and have better control over changing colors. The size of the vector icon will be adapted automatically. Refer to [SVG PathData](http://www.w3.org/TR/SVG/paths.html#PathData) for more information about the format of the path. You may export vector paths from tools like Adobe

For example:

```
'path://M30.9,53.2C16.8,53.2,5.3,41.7,5.3,27.6S16.8,2,30.9,2C45,2,56.4,13.5,56.4,27.6S45,53.2,30.9,53.2z M30.9,3.5C17.6,3.5,6.8,14.4,6.8,27.6c0,13.3,10.8,24.1,24.101,24.1C44.2,51.7,55,40.9,55,27.6C54.9,14.4,44.1,3.5,30.9,3.5z M36.9,35.8c0,0.601-0.4,1-0.9,1h-1.3c-0.5,0-0.9-0.399-0.9-1V19.5c0-0.6,0.4-1,0.9-1H36c0.5,0,0.9,0.4,0.9,1V35.8z M27.8,35.8 c0,0.601-0.4,1-0.9,1h-1.3c-0.5,0-0.9-0.399-0.9-1V19.5c0-0.6,0.4-1,0.9-1H27c0.5,0,0.9,0.4,0.9,1L27.8,35.8L27.8,35.8z'
```

markLine.data.1.symbolSize.desc: 1 symbol size. It can be set to single numbers like `10`, or use an array to represent width and height. For example, `[20, 10]` means symbol width is `20`, and height is`10`.

markLine.data.1.symbolRotate.desc: Rotate degree of 1 symbol. The negative value represents clockwise. Note that when `symbol` is set to be `'arrow'` in `markLine`, `symbolRotate` value will be ignored, and compulsively use tangent angle.

markLine.data.1.symbolKeepAspect.desc: Whether to keep aspect for symbols in the form of `path://`.

markLine.data.1.symbolOffset.desc:
Offset of 1 symbol relative to original position. By default, symbol will be put in the center position of data. But if symbol is from user-defined vector path or image, you may not expect symbol to be in center. In this case, you may use this attribute to set offset to default position. It can be in absolute pixel value, or in relative percentage value.

For example, `[0, '-50%']` means to move upside side position of symbol height. It can be used to make the arrow in the bottom to be at data position when symbol is pin.

markLine.data.1.lineStyle.desc: Line style of this data item, which will be merged with `lineStyle` of starting point and ending point.

markLine.data.1.lineStyle.color.desc:
Line color.





> Supports setting as solid color using `rgb(255,255,255)`, `rgba(255,255,255,1)`, `#fff`, etc. Also supports setting as gradient color and pattern fill, see [option.color](~color) for details

markLine.data.1.lineStyle.type.desc:
line type.


Possible values are:
+ `'solid'`
+ `'dashed'`
+ `'dotted'`

Since `v5.0.0`, it can also be a number or a number array to specify the [dash array](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/SVG/Attribute/stroke-dasharray) of the line. With
`dashOffset`
, we can make the line style more flexible.

For example：
```js
{

type: [5, 10],

dashOffset: 5
}
```

markLine.data.1.lineStyle.dashOffset.desc:
> Since `v5.0.0`





To set the line dash offset. With
`type`
, we can make the line style more flexible.

Refer to MDN [lineDashOffset](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/lineDashOffset) for more details.

markLine.data.1.lineStyle.cap.desc:
> Since `v5.0.0`





To specify how to draw the end points of the line.
Possible values are:
+ `'butt'`: The ends of lines are squared off at the endpoints.
+ `'round'`: The ends of lines are rounded.
+ `'square'`: The ends of lines are squared off by adding a box with an equal width and half the height of the line's thickness.

Default value is `'butt'`. Refer to MDN [lineCap](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/lineCap) for more details.

markLine.data.1.lineStyle.join.desc:
> Since `v5.0.0`





To determine the shape used to join two line segments where they meet.

Possible values are:
+ `'bevel'`: Fills an additional triangular area between the common endpoint of connected segments, and the separate outside rectangular corners of each segment.
+ `'round'`: Rounds off the corners of a shape by filling an additional sector of disc centered at the common endpoint of connected segments. The radius for these rounded corners is equal to the line width.
+ `'miter'`: Connected segments are joined by extending their outside edges to connect at a single point, with the effect of filling an additional lozenge-shaped area. This setting is affected by the
`miterLimit`
property.

Default value is `'bevel'`. Refer to MDN [lineJoin](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/lineJoin) for more details.

markLine.data.1.lineStyle.miterLimit.desc:
> Since `v5.0.0`





To set the miter limit ratio. Only works when
`join`
is set as `miter`.

Default value is `10`. Negative、`0`、`Infinity` and `NaN` values are ignored.

Refer to MDN [miterLimit](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/miterLimit) for more details.

markLine.data.1.lineStyle.shadowBlur.desc:
Size of shadow blur. This attribute should be used along with `shadowColor`,`shadowOffsetX`, `shadowOffsetY` to set shadow to component.

For example:
```js
{
shadowColor: 'rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.5)',
shadowBlur: 10
}
```

markLine.data.1.lineStyle.shadowColor.desc: Shadow color. Support same format as `color`.

markLine.data.1.lineStyle.shadowOffsetX.desc: Offset distance on the horizontal direction of shadow.

markLine.data.1.lineStyle.shadowOffsetY.desc: Offset distance on the vertical direction of shadow.

markLine.data.1.lineStyle.opacity.desc: Opacity of the component. Supports value from 0 to 1, and the component will not be drawn when set to 0.

markLine.data.1.lineStyle.curveness.desc: Edge curvature, which supports value from 0 to 1. The larger the value, the greater the curvature.

markLine.data.1.label.desc: Label of this data item, which will be merged with `label` of starting point and ending point.

markLine.data.1.label.position.desc:
Positions of labels can be:
+ `'start'` starting point of the line.
+ `'middle'` middle point of the line.
+ `'end'` ending point of the line.

Since version 4.7.0, more label positions are supported: `'start'`, `'middle'`, `'end'`, `'insideStartTop'`, `'insideStartBottom'`, `'insideMiddleTop'`, `'insideMiddleBottom'`, `'insideEndTop'`, `'insideEndBottom'`.

`'insideMiddleBottom'` is the same as `'middle'`. Position is as the following chart.

The distance between labels and mark lines can be set with [label.distance](~series-.markLine.label.distance).

~[800x500](bar-markline&reset=1&edit=1)

markLine.data.1.label.distance.desc: The distance between labels and mark lines. If it's an array, then the first element is the horizontal distance, and the second element is the vertical distance. If it's a number, then the horizontal and vertical distances are the same.

Since version 4.7.0, more label positions are supported: `'start'`, `'middle'`, `'end'`, `'insideStartTop'`, `'insideStartBottom'`, `'insideMiddleTop'`, `'insideMiddleBottom'`, `'insideEndTop'`, `'insideEndBottom'`.

`'insideMiddleBottom'` is the same as `'middle'`. Position is as the following chart.

The distance between labels and mark lines can be set with [label.distance](~series-.markLine.label.distance).

~[800x500](bar-markline&reset=1&edit=1)

markLine.data.1.emphasis.label.distance.desc: The distance between labels and mark lines. If it's an array, then the first element is the horizontal distance, and the second element is the vertical distance. If it's a number, then the horizontal and vertical distances are the same.

markLine.data.1.blur.lineStyle.color.desc:
Line color.





> Supports setting as solid color using `rgb(255,255,255)`, `rgba(255,255,255,1)`, `#fff`, etc. Also supports setting as gradient color and pattern fill, see [option.color](~color) for details

markLine.data.1.blur.lineStyle.type.desc:
line type.


Possible values are:
+ `'solid'`
+ `'dashed'`
+ `'dotted'`

Since `v5.0.0`, it can also be a number or a number array to specify the [dash array](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/SVG/Attribute/stroke-dasharray) of the line. With
`dashOffset`
, we can make the line style more flexible.

For example：
```js
{

type: [5, 10],

dashOffset: 5
}
```

markLine.data.1.blur.lineStyle.dashOffse.desc:
> Since `v5.0.0`





To set the line dash offset. With
`type`
, we can make the line style more flexible.

Refer to MDN [lineDashOffset](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/lineDashOffset) for more details.

markLine.data.1.blur.lineStyle.cap.desc:
> Since `v5.0.0`





To specify how to draw the end points of the line.
Possible values are:
+ `'butt'`: The ends of lines are squared off at the endpoints.
+ `'round'`: The ends of lines are rounded.
+ `'square'`: The ends of lines are squared off by adding a box with an equal width and half the height of the line's thickness.

Default value is `'butt'`. Refer to MDN [lineCap](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/lineCap) for more details.

markLine.data.1.blur.lineStyle.join.desc:
> Since `v5.0.0`





To determine the shape used to join two line segments where they meet.

Possible values are:
+ `'bevel'`: Fills an additional triangular area between the common endpoint of connected segments, and the separate outside rectangular corners of each segment.
+ `'round'`: Rounds off the corners of a shape by filling an additional sector of disc centered at the common endpoint of connected segments. The radius for these rounded corners is equal to the line width.
+ `'miter'`: Connected segments are joined by extending their outside edges to connect at a single point, with the effect of filling an additional lozenge-shaped area. This setting is affected by the
`miterLimit`
property.

Default value is `'bevel'`. Refer to MDN [lineJoin](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/lineJoin) for more details.

markLine.data.1.blur.lineStyle.miterLimi.desc:
> Since `v5.0.0`





To set the miter limit ratio. Only works when
`join`
is set as `miter`.

Default value is `10`. Negative、`0`、`Infinity` and `NaN` values are ignored.

Refer to MDN [miterLimit](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/miterLimit) for more details.

markLine.data.1.blur.lineStyle.shadowBlu.desc:
Size of shadow blur. This attribute should be used along with `shadowColor`,`shadowOffsetX`, `shadowOffsetY` to set shadow to component.

For example:
```js
{
shadowColor: 'rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.5)',
shadowBlur: 10
}
```

markLine.data.1.blur.lineStyle.shadowCol.desc: Shadow color. Support same format as `color`.

markLine.data.1.blur.lineStyle.shadowOff.desc: Offset distance on the horizontal direction of shadow.
Offset distance on the vertical direction of shadow.

markLine.data.1.blur.lineStyle.opacity.desc: Opacity of the component. Supports value from 0 to 1, and the component will not be drawn when set to 0.

markLine.data.1.blur.lineStyle.curveness.desc: Edge curvature, which supports value from 0 to 1. The larger the value, the greater the curvature.

markLine.animationThreshold.desc: Whether to set graphic number threshold to animation. Animation will be disabled when graphic number is larger than threshold.

markLine.animationEasing.desc: Easing method used for the first animation. Varied easing effects can be found at [easing effect example](line-easing).

markArea.desc: Used to mark an area in chart. For example, mark a time interval.

markArea.silent.desc: Whether to ignore mouse events. Default value is false, for triggering and responding to mouse events.

markArea.label.position.desc:
Label position.

**Followings are the options: **

+ [x, y]

Use relative percentage, or absolute pixel values to represent position of label relative to top-left corner of bounding box.
For example:
```js
// Absolute pixel values
position: [10, 10],
// Relative percentage
position: ['50%', '50%']
```

+ 'top'
+ 'left'
+ 'right'
+ 'bottom'
+ 'inside'
+ 'insideLeft'
+ 'insideRight'
+ 'insideTop'
+ 'insideBottom'
+ 'insideTopLeft'
+ 'insideBottomLeft'
+ 'insideTopRight'
+ 'insideBottomRight'

See: [label position](doc-example/label-position).

markArea.label.distance.desc:
Distance to the host graphic element.


It is valid only when `position` is string value (like `'top'`、`'insideRight'`).

See: [label position](doc-example/label-position).

markArea.label.rotate.desc:
Rotate label, from -90 degree to 90, positive value represents rotate anti-clockwise.

See: [label rotation](bar-label-rotation).

markArea.label.offset.desc: Whether to move text slightly. For example: `[30, 40]` means move `30` horizontally and move `40` vertically.

markArea.label.rich.<style_name>.padding.desc:
Padding of the text fragment, for example:

+ `padding: [3, 4, 5, 6]`: represents padding of `[top, right, bottom, left]`.
+ `padding: 4`: represents `padding: [4, 4, 4, 4]`.
+ `padding: [3, 4]`: represents `padding: [3, 4, 3, 4]`.

Notice, `width` and `height` specifies the width and height of the content, without `padding`.

markArea.label.rich.<style_name>.shadowC.desc: Shadow color of the text block.

Shadow Y offset of the text block.

markArea.label.rich.<style_name>.width.desc:
Width of the text block. It is the width of the text by default. In most cases, there is no need to specify it. You may want to use it in some cases like make simple table or using background image (see `backgroundColor`).

Notice, `width` and `height` specifies the width and height of the content, without `padding`.

`width` can also be percent string, like `'100%'`, which represents the percent of `contentWidth` (that is, the width without `padding`) of its container box. It is based on `contentWidth` because that each text fragment is layout based on the `content box`, where it makes no sense that calculating width based on `outerWith` in prectice.


Notice, `width` and `height` only work when `rich` specified.

markArea.label.rich.<style_name>.height.desc:
Height of the text block. It is the width of the text by default. You may want to use it in some cases like using background image (see `backgroundColor`).

Notice, `width` and `height` specifies the width and height of the content, without `padding`.

Notice, `width` and `height` only work when `rich` specified.

markArea.itemStyle.borderColor.desc: border color, whose format is similar to that of `color`.

markArea.itemStyle.borderWidth.desc:
border width. No border when it is set to be 0.

(${name} ? ${name} : "") + " border width. No border when it is set to be 0."

markArea.itemStyle.borderType.desc:
border type.



Possible values are:
+ `'solid'`
+ `'dashed'`
+ `'dotted'`

Since `v5.0.0`, it can also be a number or a number array to specify the [dash array](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/SVG/Attribute/stroke-dasharray) of the line. With
`borderDashOffset`
, we can make the line style more flexible.

For example：
```js
{

borderType: [5, 10],

borderDashOffset: 5
}
```

markArea.itemStyle.borderDashOffset.desc:
> Since `v5.0.0`





To set the line dash offset. With
`borderType`
, we can make the line style more flexible.

Refer to MDN [lineDashOffset](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/lineDashOffset) for more details.

markArea.itemStyle.borderCap.desc:
> Since `v5.0.0`





To specify how to draw the end points of the line.
Possible values are:
+ `'butt'`: The ends of lines are squared off at the endpoints.
+ `'round'`: The ends of lines are rounded.
+ `'square'`: The ends of lines are squared off by adding a box with an equal width and half the height of the line's thickness.

Default value is `'butt'`. Refer to MDN [lineCap](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/lineCap) for more details.

markArea.itemStyle.borderJoin.desc:
> Since `v5.0.0`





To determine the shape used to join two line segments where they meet.

Possible values are:
+ `'bevel'`: Fills an additional triangular area between the common endpoint of connected segments, and the separate outside rectangular corners of each segment.
+ `'round'`: Rounds off the corners of a shape by filling an additional sector of disc centered at the common endpoint of connected segments. The radius for these rounded corners is equal to the line width.
+ `'miter'`: Connected segments are joined by extending their outside edges to connect at a single point, with the effect of filling an additional lozenge-shaped area. This setting is affected by the
`borderMiterLimit`
property.

Default value is `'bevel'`. Refer to MDN [lineJoin](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/lineJoin) for more details.

markArea.itemStyle.borderMiterLimit.desc:
> Since `v5.0.0`





To set the miter limit ratio. Only works when
`borderJoin`
is set as `miter`.

Default value is `10`. Negative、`0`、`Infinity` and `NaN` values are ignored.

Refer to MDN [miterLimit](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/miterLimit) for more details.

markArea.itemStyle.shadowBlur.desc:
Size of shadow blur. This attribute should be used along with `shadowColor`,`shadowOffsetX`, `shadowOffsetY` to set shadow to component.

For example:
```js
{
shadowColor: 'rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.5)',
shadowBlur: 10
}
```

markArea.itemStyle.shadowColor.desc: Shadow color. Support same format as `color`.

markArea.itemStyle.shadowOffsetX.desc: Offset distance on the horizontal direction of shadow.

markArea.itemStyle.shadowOffsetY.desc: Offset distance on the vertical direction of shadow.

markArea.itemStyle.opacity.desc: Opacity of the component. Supports value from 0 to 1, and the component will not be drawn when set to 0.

markArea.blur.label.rich.<style_name>.wi.desc:
Width of the text block. It is the width of the text by default. In most cases, there is no need to specify it. You may want to use it in some cases like make simple table or using background image (see `backgroundColor`).

Notice, `width` and `height` specifies the width and height of the content, without `padding`.

`width` can also be percent string, like `'100%'`, which represents the percent of `contentWidth` (that is, the width without `padding`) of its container box. It is based on `contentWidth` because that each text fragment is layout based on the `content box`, where it makes no sense that calculating width based on `outerWith` in prectice.


Notice, `width` and `height` only work when `rich` specified.

markArea.blur.itemStyle.borderColor.desc: border color, whose format is similar to that of `color`.

markArea.blur.itemStyle.borderWidth.desc:
border width. No border when it is set to be 0.

(${name} ? ${name} : "") + " border width. No border when it is set to be 0."

markArea.blur.itemStyle.borderType.desc:
border type.



Possible values are:
+ `'solid'`
+ `'dashed'`
+ `'dotted'`

Since `v5.0.0`, it can also be a number or a number array to specify the [dash array](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/SVG/Attribute/stroke-dasharray) of the line. With
`borderDashOffset`
, we can make the line style more flexible.

For example：
```js
{

borderType: [5, 10],

borderDashOffset: 5
}
```

markArea.blur.itemStyle.borderDashOffset.desc:
> Since `v5.0.0`





To set the line dash offset. With
`borderType`
, we can make the line style more flexible.

Refer to MDN [lineDashOffset](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/lineDashOffset) for more details.

markArea.blur.itemStyle.borderCap.desc:
> Since `v5.0.0`





To specify how to draw the end points of the line.
Possible values are:
+ `'butt'`: The ends of lines are squared off at the endpoints.
+ `'round'`: The ends of lines are rounded.
+ `'square'`: The ends of lines are squared off by adding a box with an equal width and half the height of the line's thickness.

Default value is `'butt'`. Refer to MDN [lineCap](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/lineCap) for more details.

markArea.blur.itemStyle.borderJoin.desc:
> Since `v5.0.0`





To determine the shape used to join two line segments where they meet.

Possible values are:
+ `'bevel'`: Fills an additional triangular area between the common endpoint of connected segments, and the separate outside rectangular corners of each segment.
+ `'round'`: Rounds off the corners of a shape by filling an additional sector of disc centered at the common endpoint of connected segments. The radius for these rounded corners is equal to the line width.
+ `'miter'`: Connected segments are joined by extending their outside edges to connect at a single point, with the effect of filling an additional lozenge-shaped area. This setting is affected by the
`borderMiterLimit`
property.

Default value is `'bevel'`. Refer to MDN [lineJoin](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/lineJoin) for more details.

markArea.blur.itemStyle.borderMiterLimit.desc:
> Since `v5.0.0`





To set the miter limit ratio. Only works when
`borderJoin`
is set as `miter`.

Default value is `10`. Negative、`0`、`Infinity` and `NaN` values are ignored.

Refer to MDN [miterLimit](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/miterLimit) for more details.

markArea.blur.itemStyle.shadowBlur.desc:
Size of shadow blur. This attribute should be used along with `shadowColor`,`shadowOffsetX`, `shadowOffsetY` to set shadow to component.

For example:
```js
{
shadowColor: 'rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.5)',
shadowBlur: 10
}
```

color.



> Supports setting as solid color using `rgb(255,255,255)`, `rgba(255,255,255,1)`, `#fff`, etc. Also supports setting as gradient color and pattern fill, see [option.color](~color) for details

markArea.data.0.blur.itemStyle.borderCol.desc: border color, whose format is similar to that of `color`.

markArea.data.0.blur.itemStyle.borderWid.desc:
border width. No border when it is set to be 0.

(${name} ? ${name} : "") + " border width. No border when it is set to be 0."

markArea.data.0.blur.itemStyle.borderTyp.desc:
border type.



Possible values are:
+ `'solid'`
+ `'dashed'`
+ `'dotted'`

Since `v5.0.0`, it can also be a number or a number array to specify the [dash array](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/SVG/Attribute/stroke-dasharray) of the line. With
`borderDashOffset`
, we can make the line style more flexible.

For example：
```js
{

borderType: [5, 10],

borderDashOffset: 5
}
```

markArea.data.0.blur.itemStyle.borderDas.desc:
> Since `v5.0.0`





To set the line dash offset. With
`borderType`
, we can make the line style more flexible.

Refer to MDN [lineDashOffset](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/lineDashOffset) for more details.

markArea.data.0.blur.itemStyle.borderCap.desc:
> Since `v5.0.0`





To specify how to draw the end points of the line.
Possible values are:
+ `'butt'`: The ends of lines are squared off at the endpoints.
+ `'round'`: The ends of lines are rounded.
+ `'square'`: The ends of lines are squared off by adding a box with an equal width and half the height of the line's thickness.

Default value is `'butt'`. Refer to MDN [lineCap](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/lineCap) for more details.

markArea.data.0.blur.itemStyle.borderJoi.desc:
> Since `v5.0.0`





To determine the shape used to join two line segments where they meet.

Possible values are:
+ `'bevel'`: Fills an additional triangular area between the common endpoint of connected segments, and the separate outside rectangular corners of each segment.
+ `'round'`: Rounds off the corners of a shape by filling an additional sector of disc centered at the common endpoint of connected segments. The radius for these rounded corners is equal to the line width.
+ `'miter'`: Connected segments are joined by extending their outside edges to connect at a single point, with the effect of filling an additional lozenge-shaped area. This setting is affected by the
`borderMiterLimit`
property.

Default value is `'bevel'`. Refer to MDN [lineJoin](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/lineJoin) for more details.

markArea.data.0.blur.itemStyle.borderMit.desc:
> Since `v5.0.0`





To set the miter limit ratio. Only works when
`borderJoin`
is set as `miter`.

Default value is `10`. Negative、`0`、`Infinity` and `NaN` values are ignored.

Refer to MDN [miterLimit](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/miterLimit) for more details.

markArea.data.0.blur.itemStyle.shadowBlu.desc:
Size of shadow blur. This attribute should be used along with `shadowColor`,`shadowOffsetX`, `shadowOffsetY` to set shadow to component.

For example:
```js
{
shadowColor: 'rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.5)',
shadowBlur: 10
}
```

markArea.data.0.blur.itemStyle.shadowCol.desc: Shadow color. Support same format as `color`.

markArea.data.0.blur.itemStyle.shadowOff.desc: Offset distance on the horizontal direction of shadow.
Offset distance on the vertical direction of shadow.

markArea.data.0.blur.itemStyle.opacity.desc: Opacity of the component. Supports value from 0 to 1, and the component will not be drawn when set to 0.

markArea.data.0.blur.label.position.desc:
Label position.

**Followings are the options: **

+ [x, y]

Use relative percentage, or absolute pixel values to represent position of label relative to top-left corner of bounding box.
For example:
```js
// Absolute pixel values
position: [10, 10],
// Relative percentage
position: ['50%', '50%']
```

+ 'top'
+ 'left'
+ 'right'
+ 'bottom'
+ 'inside'
+ 'insideLeft'
+ 'insideRight'

+ 'insideBottomRight'

See: [label rotation](bar-label-rotation).

markArea.data.0.blur.label.offset.desc: Whether to move text slightly. For example: `[30, 40]` means move `30` horizontally and move `40` vertically.

markArea.data.1.emphasis.itemStyle.color.desc:
color.



> Supports setting as solid color using `rgb(255,255,255)`, `rgba(255,255,255,1)`, `#fff`, etc. Also supports setting as gradient color and pattern fill, see [option.color](~color) for details

markArea.data.1.emphasis.itemStyle.borde.desc: border color, whose format is similar to that of `color`.

border width. No border when it is set to be 0.

(${name} ? ${name} : "") + " border width. No border when it is set to be 0."

border type.



Possible values are:
+ `'solid'`
+ `'dashed'`
+ `'dotted'`

Since `v5.0.0`, it can also be a number or a number array to specify the [dash array](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/SVG/Attribute/stroke-dasharray) of the line. With
`borderDashOffset`
, we can make the line style more flexible.

For example：
```js
{

borderType: [5, 10],

borderDashOffset: 5
}
```

> Since `v5.0.0`





To set the line dash offset. With
`borderType`
, we can make the line style more flexible.

Refer to MDN [lineDashOffset](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/lineDashOffset) for more details.

> Since `v5.0.0`





To specify how to draw the end points of the line.
Possible values are:
+ `'butt'`: The ends of lines are squared off at the endpoints.
+ `'round'`: The ends of lines are rounded.
+ `'square'`: The ends of lines are squared off by adding a box with an equal width and half the height of the line's thickness.

Default value is `'butt'`. Refer to MDN [lineCap](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/lineCap) for more details.

> Since `v5.0.0`





To determine the shape used to join two line segments where they meet.

Possible values are:
+ `'bevel'`: Fills an additional triangular area between the common endpoint of connected segments, and the separate outside rectangular corners of each segment.
+ `'round'`: Rounds off the corners of a shape by filling an additional sector of disc centered at the common endpoint of connected segments. The radius for these rounded corners is equal to the line width.
+ `'miter'`: Connected segments are joined by extending their outside edges to connect at a single point, with the effect of filling an additional lozenge-shaped area. This setting is affected by the
`borderMiterLimit`
property.

Default value is `'bevel'`. Refer to MDN [lineJoin](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/lineJoin) for more details.

> Since `v5.0.0`





To set the miter limit ratio. Only works when
`borderJoin`
is set as `miter`.

Default value is `10`. Negative、`0`、`Infinity` and `NaN` values are ignored.

Refer to MDN [miterLimit](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/CanvasRenderingContext2D/miterLimit) for more details.

markArea.data.1.emphasis.itemStyle.shado.desc:
Size of shadow blur. This attribute should be used along with `shadowColor`,`shadowOffsetX`, `shadowOffsetY` to set shadow to component.

For example:
```js
{
shadowColor: 'rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.5)',
shadowBlur: 10
}
```
Shadow color. Support same format as `color`.
Offset distance on the horizontal direction of shadow.
Offset distance on the vertical direction of shadow.

markArea.data.1.emphasis.itemStyle.opaci.desc: Opacity of the component. Supports value from 0 to 1, and the component will not be drawn when set to 0.

markArea.data.1.emphasis.label.position.desc:
Label position.

**Followings are the options: **

+ [x, y]

Use relative percentage, or absolute pixel values to represent position of label relative to top-left corner of bounding box.
For example:
```js
// Absolute pixel values
position: [10, 10],
// Relative percentage
position: ['50%', '50%']
```

+ 'top'
+ 'left'
+ 'right'
+ 'bottom'
+ 'inside'
+ 'insideLeft'
+ 'insideRight'
+ 'insideTop'
+ 'insideBottom'

+ 'insideTopRight'
+ 'insideBottomRight'

See: [label position](doc-example/label-position).

markArea.data.1.emphasis.label.distance.desc:

It is valid only when `position` is string value (like `'top'`、`'insideRight'`).

See: [label position](doc-example/label-position).

See: [label rotation](bar-label-rotation).

markArea.data.1.emphasis.label.offset.desc: Whether to move text slightly. For example: `[30, 40]` means move `30` horizontally and move `40` vertically.

markArea.data.1.blur.label.borderRadius.desc: Border radius of the text fragment.

markArea.data.1.blur.label.padding.desc:
Padding of the text fragment, for example:

+ `padding: [3, 4, 5, 6]`: represents padding of `[top, right, bottom, left]`.
+ `padding: 4`: represents `padding: [4, 4, 4, 4]`.
+ `padding: [3, 4]`: represents `padding: [3, 4, 3, 4]`.

Notice, `width` and `height` specifies the width and height of the content, without `padding`.

markArea.data.1.blur.label.shadowBlur.desc: Show blur of the text block.

markArea.data.1.blur.label.shadowOffsetY.desc: Shadow Y offset of the text block.

If set as `'inherit'`, the color will assigned as visual color, such as series color.

markArea.data.1.blur.label.textBorderWid.desc: Storke line width of the text.

markArea.data.1.blur.label.textBorderTyp.desc:
Stroke line type of the text.


Possible values are:
+ `'solid'`
+ `'dashed'`
+ `'dotted'`

Since `v5.0.0`, it can also be a number or a number array to specify the [dash array](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/SVG/Attribute/stroke-dasharray) of the line. With
`textBorderDashOffset`
, we can make the line style more flexible.

For example：
```js
{

textBorderType: [5, 10],

textBorderDashOffset: 5
}
```

markArea.data.1.blur.label.overflow.desc:
Determine how to display the text when it's overflow. Available when `width` is set.

+ `'truncate'` Truncate the text and trailing with `ellipsis`.
+ `'break'` Break by word
+ `'breakAll'` Break by character.

markArea.data.1.blur.label.ellipsis.desc: Ellipsis to be displayed when `overflow` is set to `truncate`.

markArea.data.1.blur.label.lineOverflow.desc:
Determine how to display the text when it's overflow on height.

+ `'truncate'` Truncate the overflow lines.
